<span id="ln_003a-Make-links-between-files"></span>

### 12.2 `ln`: Make links between files

<span id="index-ln"></span> <span
id="index-links_002c-creating-1"></span> <span
id="index-hard-links_002c-creating-1"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-_0028soft_0029-links_002c-creating"></span> <span
id="index-creating-links-_0028hard-or-soft_0029"></span> <span
id="index-file-systems-and-hard-links"></span>

`ln` makes links between files. By default, it makes hard links; with
the `-s` option, it makes symbolic (or *soft*) links. Synopses:

<div class="example">

``` example
ln [option]… [-T] target linkname
ln [option]… target
ln [option]… target… directory
ln [option]… -t directory target…
```

</div>

-   If two file names are given, `ln` creates a link to the first file
    from the second.
-   If one `target` is given, `ln` creates a link to that file in the
    current directory.
-   If the `--target-directory` (`-t`) option is given, or failing that
    if the last file is a directory and the `--no-target-directory`
    (`-T`) option is not given, `ln` creates a link to each `target`
    file in the specified directory, using the `target`s’ names.

Normally `ln` does not replace existing files. Use the `--force` (`-f`)
option to replace them unconditionally, the `--interactive` (`-i`)
option to replace them conditionally, and the `--backup` (`-b`) option
to rename them. Unless the `--backup` (`-b`) option is used there is no
brief moment when the destination does not exist; this is an extension
to POSIX.

<span id="index-hard-link_002c-defined"></span> <span
id="index-inode_002c-and-hard-links"></span>

A *hard link* is another name for an existing file; the link and the
original are indistinguishable. Technically speaking, they share the
same inode, and the inode contains all the information about a
file—indeed, it is not incorrect to say that the inode *is* the file.
Most systems prohibit making a hard link to a directory; on those where
it is allowed, only the super-user can do so (and with caution, since
creating a cycle will cause problems to many other utilities). Hard
links cannot cross file system boundaries. (These restrictions are not
mandated by POSIX, however.)

<span id="index-dereferencing-symbolic-links"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-link_002c-defined"></span>

*Symbolic links* (*symlinks* for short), on the other hand, are a
special file type (which not all kernels support: System V release 3
(and older) systems lack symlinks) in which the link file actually
refers to a different file, by name. When most operations (opening,
reading, writing, and so on) are passed the symbolic link file, the
kernel automatically *dereferences* the link and operates on the target
of the link. But some operations (e.g., removing) work on the link file
itself, rather than on its target. The owner and group of a symlink are
not significant to file access performed through the link, but do have
implications on deleting a symbolic link from a directory with the
restricted deletion bit set. On the GNU system, the mode of a symlink
has no significance and cannot be changed, but on some BSD systems, the
mode can be changed and will affect whether the symlink will be
traversed in file name resolution. See [Symbolic
Links](https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#Symbolic-Links)
in The GNU C Library Reference Manual.

Symbolic links can contain arbitrary strings; a *dangling symlink*
occurs when the string in the symlink does not resolve to a file. There
are no restrictions against creating dangling symbolic links. There are
trade-offs to using absolute or relative symlinks. An absolute symlink
always points to the same file, even if the directory containing the
link is moved. However, if the symlink is visible from more than one
machine (such as on a networked file system), the file pointed to might
not always be the same. A relative symbolic link is resolved in relation
to the directory that contains the link, and is often useful in
referring to files on the same device without regards to what name that
device is mounted on when accessed via networked machines.

When creating a relative symlink in a different location than the
current directory, the resolution of the symlink will be different than
the resolution of the same string from the current directory. Therefore,
many users prefer to first change directories to the location where the
relative symlink will be created, so that tab-completion or other file
resolution will find the same target as what will be placed in the
symlink.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-b`’  
‘`--backup[=method]`’  
<span id="index-_002db-17"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dbackup-4"></span> <span
id="index-VERSION_005fCONTROL-4"></span> <span
id="index-backups_002c-making-4"></span>

See [Backup options](#Backup-options). Make a backup of each file that
would otherwise be overwritten or removed.

‘`-d`’  
‘`-F`’  
‘`--directory`’  
<span id="index-_002dd-14"></span> <span id="index-_002dF-4"></span>
<span id="index-_002d_002ddirectory-2"></span> <span
id="index-hard-links-to-directories"></span>

Allow users with appropriate privileges to attempt to make hard links to
directories. However, note that this will probably fail due to system
restrictions, even for the super-user.

‘`-f`’  
‘`--force`’  
<span id="index-_002df-14"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dforce-4"></span>

Remove existing destination files.

‘`-i`’  
‘`--interactive`’  
<span id="index-_002di-14"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dinteractive-3"></span> <span
id="index-prompting_002c-and-ln"></span>

Prompt whether to remove existing destination files.

‘`-L`’  
‘`--logical`’  
<span id="index-_002dL-4"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dlogical"></span>

If `-s` is not in effect, and the source file is a symbolic link, create
the hard link to the file referred to by the symbolic link, rather than
the symbolic link itself.

‘`-n`’  
‘`--no-dereference`’  
<span id="index-_002dn-13"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dno_002ddereference-1"></span>

Do not treat the last operand specially when it is a symbolic link to a
directory. Instead, treat it as if it were a normal file.

When the destination is an actual directory (not a symlink to one),
there is no ambiguity. The link is created in that directory. But when
the specified destination is a symlink to a directory, there are two
ways to treat the user’s request. `ln` can treat the destination just as
it would a normal directory and create the link in it. On the other
hand, the destination can be viewed as a non-directory—as the symlink
itself. In that case, `ln` must delete or backup that symlink before
creating the new link. The default is to treat a destination that is a
symlink to a directory just like a directory.

This option is weaker than the `--no-target-directory` (`-T`) option, so
it has no effect if both options are given.

‘`-P`’  
‘`--physical`’  
<span id="index-_002dP-2"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dphysical"></span>

If `-s` is not in effect, and the source file is a symbolic link, create
the hard link to the symbolic link itself. On platforms where this is
not supported by the kernel, this option creates a symbolic link with
identical contents; since symbolic link contents cannot be edited, any
file name resolution performed through either link will be the same as
if a hard link had been created.

‘`-r`’  
‘`--relative`’  
<span id="index-_002dr-9"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002drelative"></span>

Make symbolic links relative to the link location. This option is only
valid with the `--symbolic` option.

Example:

<div class="example">

``` example
ln -srv /a/file /tmp
'/tmp/file' -> '../a/file'
```

</div>

Relative symbolic links are generated based on their canonicalized
containing directory, and canonicalized targets. I.e., all symbolic
links in these file names will be resolved. See [realpath
invocation](#realpath-invocation), which gives greater control over
relative file name generation, as demonstrated in the following example:

<div class="example">

``` verbatim
ln--relative() {
  test "$1" = --no-symlinks && { nosym=$1; shift; }
  target="$1";
  test -d "$2" && link="$2/." || link="$2"
  rtarget="$(realpath $nosym -m "$target" \
              --relative-to "$(dirname "$link")")"
  ln -s -v "$rtarget" "$link"
}
```

</div>

‘`-s`’  
‘`--symbolic`’  
<span id="index-_002ds-18"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dsymbolic"></span>

Make symbolic links instead of hard links. This option merely produces
an error message on systems that do not support symbolic links.

‘`-S suffix`’  
‘`--suffix=suffix`’  
<span id="index-_002dS-9"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dsuffix-4"></span>

Append `suffix` to each backup file made with `-b`. See [Backup
options](#Backup-options).

‘`-t directory`’  
‘`--target-directory=directory`’  
<span id="index-_002dt-14"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dtarget_002ddirectory-4"></span> <span
id="index-target-directory-9"></span> <span
id="index-destination-directory-8"></span>

Specify the destination `directory`. See [Target
directory](#Target-directory).

‘`-T`’  
‘`--no-target-directory`’  
<span id="index-_002dT-8"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dno_002dtarget_002ddirectory-4"></span> <span
id="index-target-directory-10"></span> <span
id="index-destination-directory-9"></span>

Do not treat the last operand specially when it is a directory or a
symbolic link to a directory. See [Target directory](#Target-directory).

‘`-v`’  
‘`--verbose`’  
<span id="index-_002dv-12"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dverbose-8"></span>

Print the name of each file after linking it successfully.

<span id="index-hard-links-to-symbolic-links"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-links-and-ln"></span>

If `-L` and `-P` are both given, the last one takes precedence. If `-s`
is also given, `-L` and `-P` are silently ignored. If neither option is
given, then this implementation defaults to `-P` if the system `link`
supports hard links to symbolic links (such as the GNU system), and `-L`
if `link` follows symbolic links (such as on BSD).

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

Examples:

<div class="example">

``` example
Bad Example:

# Create link ../a pointing to a in that directory.
# Not really useful because it points to itself.
ln -s a ..

Better Example:

# Change to the target before creating symlinks to avoid being confused.
cd ..
ln -s adir/a .

Bad Example:

# Hard coded file names don't move well.
ln -s $(pwd)/a /some/dir/

Better Example:

# Relative file names survive directory moves and also
# work across networked file systems.
ln -s afile anotherfile
ln -s ../adir/afile yetanotherfile
```

</div>

<span id="mkdir_003a-Make-directories"></span>

### 12.3 `mkdir`: Make directories

<span id="index-mkdir"></span> <span
id="index-directories_002c-creating"></span> <span
id="index-creating-directories"></span>

`mkdir` creates directories with the specified names. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
mkdir [option]… name…
```

</div>

`mkdir` creates each directory `name` in the order given. It reports an
error if `name` already exists, unless the `-p` option is given and
`name` is a directory.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-m mode`’  
‘`--mode=mode`’  
<span id="index-_002dm-5"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dmode-1"></span> <span
id="index-modes-of-created-directories_002c-setting"></span>

Set the file permission bits of created directories to `mode`, which
uses the same syntax as in `chmod` and uses ‘`a=rwx`’ (read, write and
execute allowed for everyone) for the point of the departure. See [File
permissions](#File-permissions). This option affects only directories
given on the command line; it does not affect any parents that may be
created via the `-p` option.

Normally the directory has the desired file mode bits at the moment it
is created. As a GNU extension, `mode` may also mention special mode
bits, but in this case there may be a temporary window during which the
directory exists but its special mode bits are incorrect. See [Directory
Setuid and Setgid](#Directory-Setuid-and-Setgid), for how the
set-user-ID and set-group-ID bits of directories are inherited unless
overridden in this way.

‘`-p`’  
‘`--parents`’  
<span id="index-_002dp-5"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dparents-1"></span> <span
id="index-parent-directories_002c-creating"></span>

Make any missing parent directories for each argument, setting their
file permission bits to ‘`=rwx,u+wx`’, that is, with the umask modified
by ‘`u+wx`’. Ignore existing parent directories, and do not change their
file permission bits.

If the `-m` option is also given, it does not affect file permission
bits of any newly-created parent directories. To control these bits, set
the umask before invoking `mkdir`. For example, if the shell command
‘`(umask u=rwx,go=rx; mkdir -p P/Q)`’ creates the parent `P` it sets the
parent’s file permission bits to ‘`u=rwx,go=rx`’. (The umask must
include ‘`u=wx`’ for this method to work.) To set a parent’s special
mode bits as well, you can invoke `chmod` after `mkdir`. See [Directory
Setuid and Setgid](#Directory-Setuid-and-Setgid), for how the
set-user-ID and set-group-ID bits of newly-created parent directories
are inherited.

‘`-v`’  
‘`--verbose`’  
<span id="index-_002dv-13"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dverbose-9"></span>

Print a message for each created directory. This is most useful with
`--parents`.

‘`-Z`’  
‘`--context[=context]`’  
<span id="index-_002dZ-4"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dcontext-4"></span> <span
id="index-SELinux_002c-setting_002frestoring-security-context-2"></span>
<span id="index-security-context-5"></span>

Without a specified `context`, adjust the SELinux security context
according to the system default type for destination files, similarly to
the `restorecon` command. The long form of this option with a specific
context specified, will set the context for newly created files only.
With a specified context, if both SELinux and SMACK are disabled, a
warning is issued.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span id="mkfifo_003a-Make-FIFOs-_0028named-pipes_0029"></span>

### 12.4 `mkfifo`: Make FIFOs (named pipes)

<span id="index-mkfifo"></span> <span
id="index-FIFOs_002c-creating"></span> <span
id="index-named-pipes_002c-creating"></span> <span
id="index-creating-FIFOs-_0028named-pipes_0029"></span>

`mkfifo` creates FIFOs (also called *named pipes*) with the specified
names. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
mkfifo [option] name…
```

</div>

A *FIFO* is a special file type that permits independent processes to
communicate. One process opens the FIFO file for writing, and another
for reading, after which data can flow as with the usual anonymous pipe
in shells or elsewhere.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-m mode`’  
‘`--mode=mode`’  
<span id="index-_002dm-6"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dmode-2"></span> <span
id="index-modes-of-created-FIFOs_002c-setting"></span>

Set the mode of created FIFOs to `mode`, which is symbolic as in `chmod`
and uses ‘`a=rw`’ (read and write allowed for everyone) for the point of
departure. `mode` should specify only file permission bits. See [File
permissions](#File-permissions).

‘`-Z`’  
‘`--context[=context]`’  
<span id="index-_002dZ-5"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dcontext-5"></span> <span
id="index-SELinux_002c-setting_002frestoring-security-context-3"></span>
<span id="index-security-context-6"></span>

Without a specified `context`, adjust the SELinux security context
according to the system default type for destination files, similarly to
the `restorecon` command. The long form of this option with a specific
context specified, will set the context for newly created files only.
With a specified context, if both SELinux and SMACK are disabled, a
warning is issued.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<div class="header">

title="Table of contents">Contents</a>\]\[<a href="#Concept-index" rel="index" title="Index">Index</a>\]

</div>

<span id="mknod_003a-Make-block-or-character-special-files"></span>

### 12.5 `mknod`: Make block or character special files

<span id="index-mknod"></span> <span
id="index-block-special-files_002c-creating"></span> <span
id="index-character-special-files_002c-creating"></span>

`mknod` creates a FIFO, character special file, or block special file
with the specified name. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
mknod [option]… name type [major minor]
```

</div>

<span id="index-special-files"></span> <span
id="index-block-special-files"></span> <span
id="index-character-special-files"></span>

Unlike the phrase “special file type” above, the term *special file* has
a technical meaning on Unix: something that can generate or receive
data. Usually this corresponds to a physical piece of hardware, e.g., a
printer or a flash drive. (These files are typically created at
system-configuration time.) The `mknod` command is what creates files of
this type. Such devices can be read either a character at a time or a
“block” (many characters) at a time, hence we say there are *block
special* files and *character special* files.

<span id="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins"></span> <span
id="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with"></span>

Due to shell aliases and built-in `mknod` functions, using an unadorned
`mknod` interactively or in a script may get you different functionality
than that described here. Invoke it via `env` (i.e., `env mknod …`) to
avoid interference from the shell.

The arguments after `name` specify the type of file to make:

‘`p`’  
<span id="index-p-for-FIFO-file"></span>

for a FIFO

‘`b`’  
<span id="index-b-for-block-special-file"></span>

for a block special file

‘`c`’  
<span id="index-c-for-character-special-file"></span>

for a character special file

When making a block or character special file, the major and minor
device numbers must be given after the file type. If a major or minor
device number begins with ‘`0x`’ or ‘`0X`’, it is interpreted as
hexadecimal; otherwise, if it begins with ‘`0`’, as octal; otherwise, as
decimal.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-m mode`’  
‘`--mode=mode`’  
<span id="index-_002dm-7"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dmode-3"></span>

Set the mode of created files to `mode`, which is symbolic as in `chmod`
and uses ‘`a=rw`’ as the point of departure. `mode` should specify only
file permission bits. See [File permissions](#File-permissions).

‘`-Z`’  
‘`--context[=context]`’  
<span id="index-_002dZ-6"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dcontext-6"></span> <span
id="index-SELinux_002c-setting_002frestoring-security-context-4"></span>
<span id="index-security-context-7"></span>

Without a specified `context`, adjust the SELinux security context
according to the system default type for destination files, similarly to
the `restorecon` command. The long form of this option with a specific
context specified, will set the context for newly created files only.
With a specified context, if both SELinux and SMACK are disabled, a
warning is issued.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span
id="readlink_003a-Print-value-of-a-symlink-or-canonical-file-name"></span>

### 12.6 `readlink`: Print value of a symlink or canonical file name

<span id="index-readlink"></span> <span
id="index-displaying-value-of-a-symbolic-link"></span> <span
id="index-canonical-file-name"></span> <span
id="index-canonicalize-a-file-name"></span> <span
id="index-realpath"></span>

`readlink` may work in one of two supported modes:

‘`Readlink mode`’  
`readlink` outputs the value of the given symbolic links. If `readlink`
is invoked with an argument other than the name of a symbolic link, it
produces no output and exits with a nonzero exit code.

‘`Canonicalize mode`’  
`readlink` outputs the absolute name of the given files which contain no
`.`, `..` components nor any repeated separators (`/`) or symbolic
links. Note the `realpath` command is the preferred command to use for
canonicalization. See [realpath invocation](#realpath-invocation).

<div class="example">

``` example
readlink [option]… file…
```

</div>

By default, `readlink` operates in readlink mode.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-f`’  
‘`--canonicalize`’  
<span id="index-_002df-15"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dcanonicalize"></span>

Activate canonicalize mode. If any component of the file name except the
last one is missing or unavailable, `readlink` produces no output and
exits with a nonzero exit code. A trailing slash is ignored.

‘`-e`’  
‘`--canonicalize-existing`’  
<span id="index-_002de-4"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dcanonicalize_002dexisting"></span>

Activate canonicalize mode. If any component is missing or unavailable,
`readlink` produces no output and exits with a nonzero exit code. A
trailing slash requires that the name resolve to a directory.

‘`-m`’  
‘`--canonicalize-missing`’  
<span id="index-_002dm-8"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dcanonicalize_002dmissing"></span>

Activate canonicalize mode. If any component is missing or unavailable,
`readlink` treats it as a directory.

‘`-n`’  
‘`--no-newline`’  
<span id="index-_002dn-14"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dno_002dnewline"></span>

Do not print the output delimiter, when a single `file` is specified.
Print a warning if specified along with multiple `file`s.

‘`-s`’  
‘`-q`’  
‘`--silent`’  
‘`--quiet`’  
<span id="index-_002ds-19"></span> <span id="index-_002dq-4"></span>
<span id="index-_002d_002dsilent-3"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dquiet-4"></span>

Suppress most error messages. On by default.

‘`-v`’  
‘`--verbose`’  
<span id="index-_002dv-14"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dverbose-10"></span>

Report error messages.

‘`-z`’  
‘`--zero`’  
<span id="index-_002dz-12"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dzero-3"></span> <span
id="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines-2"></span>

Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line, rather than a
newline. This option enables other programs to parse the output even
when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.

The `readlink` utility first appeared in OpenBSD 2.1.

The `realpath` command without options, operates like `readlink` in
canonicalize mode.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span id="rmdir_003a-Remove-empty-directories"></span>

### 12.7 `rmdir`: Remove empty directories

<span id="index-rmdir"></span> <span
id="index-removing-empty-directories"></span> <span
id="index-directories_002c-removing-empty"></span>

`rmdir` removes empty directories. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
rmdir [option]… directory…
```

</div>

If any `directory` argument does not refer to an existing empty
directory, it is an error.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`--ignore-fail-on-non-empty`’  
<span
id="index-_002d_002dignore_002dfail_002don_002dnon_002dempty"></span>
<span id="index-directory-deletion_002c-ignoring-failures"></span>

Ignore each failure to remove a directory that is solely because the
directory is non-empty.

‘`-p`’  
‘`--parents`’  
<span id="index-_002dp-6"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dparents-2"></span> <span
id="index-parent-directories_002c-removing"></span>

Remove `directory`, then try to remove each component of `directory`.
So, for example, ‘`rmdir -p a/b/c`’ is similar to ‘`rmdir a/b/c a/b a`’.
As such, it fails if any of those directories turns out not to be empty.
Use the `--ignore-fail-on-non-empty` option to make it so such a failure
does not evoke a diagnostic and does not cause `rmdir` to exit
unsuccessfully.

‘`-v`’  
‘`--verbose`’  
<span id="index-_002dv-15"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dverbose-11"></span> <span
id="index-directory-deletion_002c-reporting"></span>

Give a diagnostic for each successful removal. `directory` is removed.

See [rm invocation](#rm-invocation), for how to remove non-empty
directories recursively.

To remove all empty directories under `dirname`, including directories
that become empty because other directories are removed, you can use
either of the following commands:

<div class="example">

``` example
# This uses GNU extensions.
find dirname -type d -empty -delete

# This runs on any POSIX platform.
find dirname -depth -type d -exec rmdir {} +
```

</div>

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span id="unlink_003a-Remove-files-via-the-unlink-syscall"></span>

### 12.8 `unlink`: Remove files via the unlink syscall

<span id="index-unlink"></span> <span
id="index-removing-files-or-directories-_0028via-the-unlink-syscall_0029"></span>

`unlink` deletes a single specified file name. It is a minimalist
interface to the system-provided `unlink` function. See [Deleting
Files](https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#Deleting-Files)
in The GNU C Library Reference Manual. Synopsis: It avoids the bells and
whistles of the more commonly-used `rm` command (see [rm
invocation](#rm-invocation)).

<div class="example">

``` example
unlink filename
```

</div>

On some systems `unlink` can be used to delete the name of a directory.
On others, it can be used that way only by a privileged user. In the GNU
system `unlink` can never delete the name of a directory.

The `unlink` command honors the `--help` and `--version` options. To
remove a file whose name begins with ‘`-`’, prefix the name with ‘`./`’,
e.g., ‘`unlink ./--help`’.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span id="Changing-file-attributes-1"></span>

## 13 Changing file attributes

<span id="index-changing-file-attributes"></span> <span
id="index-file-attributes_002c-changing"></span> <span
id="index-attributes_002c-file"></span>

A file is not merely its contents, a name, and a file type (see [Special
file types](#Special-file-types)). A file also has an owner (a user ID),
a group (a group ID), permissions (what the owner can do with the file,
what people in the group can do, and what everyone else can do), various
timestamps, and other information. Collectively, we call these a file’s
*attributes*.

These commands change file attributes.

|                                                                  |     |                                |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|-----|:-------------------------------|
| • <a href="#chown-invocation" accesskey="1">chown invocation</a> |     | Change file owners and groups. |
| • <a href="#chgrp-invocation" accesskey="2">chgrp invocation</a> |     | Change file groups.            |
| • <a href="#chmod-invocation" accesskey="3">chmod invocation</a> |     | Change access permissions.     |
| • <a href="#touch-invocation" accesskey="4">touch invocation</a> |     | Change file timestamps.        |

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<div class="header">

<span id="chown_003a-Change-file-owner-and-group"></span>

### 13.1 `chown`: Change file owner and group

<span id="index-chown"></span> <span
id="index-file-ownership_002c-changing"></span> <span
id="index-group-ownership_002c-changing"></span> <span
id="index-changing-file-ownership"></span> <span
id="index-changing-group-ownership"></span>

`chown` changes the user and/or group ownership of each given `file` to
`new-owner` or to the user and group of an existing reference file.
Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
chown [option]… {new-owner | --reference=ref_file} file…
```

</div>

If used, `new-owner` specifies the new owner and/or group as follows
(with no embedded white space):

<div class="example">

``` example
[owner] [ : [group] ]
```

</div>

Specifically:

`owner`  
If only an `owner` (a user name or numeric user ID) is given, that user
is made the owner of each given file, and the files’ group is not
changed.

`owner‘:’group`  
If the `owner` is followed by a colon and a `group` (a group name or
numeric group ID), with no spaces between them, the group ownership of
the files is changed as well (to `group`).

`owner‘:’`  
If a colon but no group name follows `owner`, that user is made the
owner of the files and the group of the files is changed to `owner`’s
login group.

`‘:’group`  
If the colon and following `group` are given, but the owner is omitted,
only the group of the files is changed; in this case, `chown` performs
the same function as `chgrp`.

`‘:’`  
If only a colon is given, or if `new-owner` is empty, neither the owner
nor the group is changed.

If `owner` or `group` is intended to represent a numeric user or group
ID, then you may specify it with a leading ‘`+`’. See [Disambiguating
names and IDs](#Disambiguating-names-and-IDs).

Some older scripts may still use ‘`.`’ in place of the ‘`:`’ separator.
POSIX 1003.1-2001 (see [Standards conformance](#Standards-conformance))
does not require support for that, but for backward compatibility GNU
`chown` supports ‘`.`’ so long as no ambiguity results, although it
issues a warning and support may be removed in future versions. New
scripts should avoid the use of ‘`.`’ because it is not portable, and
because it has undesirable results if the entire `owner‘.’group` happens
to identify a user whose name contains ‘`.`’.

It is system dependent whether a user can change the group to an
arbitrary one, or the more portable behavior of being restricted to
setting a group of which the user is a member.

The `chown` command sometimes clears the set-user-ID or set-group-ID
permission bits. This behavior depends on the policy and functionality
of the underlying `chown` system call, which may make system-dependent
file mode modifications outside the control of the `chown` command. For
example, the `chown` command might not affect those bits when invoked by
a user with appropriate privileges, or when the bits signify some
function other than executable permission (e.g., mandatory locking).
When in doubt, check the underlying system behavior.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-c`’  
‘`--changes`’  
<span id="index-_002dc-15"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dchanges"></span> <span
id="index-changed-owners_002c-verbosely-describing"></span>

Verbosely describe the action for each `file` whose ownership actually
changes.

‘`-f`’  
‘`--silent`’  
‘`--quiet`’  
<span id="index-_002df-16"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dsilent-4"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dquiet-5"></span> <span
id="index-error-messages_002c-omitting"></span>

Do not print error messages about files whose ownership cannot be
changed.

‘`--from=old-owner`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dfrom"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-links_002c-changing-owner"></span>

Change a `file`’s ownership only if it has current attributes specified
by `old-owner`. `old-owner` has the same form as `new-owner` described
above. This option is useful primarily from a security standpoint in
that it narrows considerably the window of potential abuse. For example,
to reflect a user ID numbering change for one user’s files without an
option like this, `root` might run

<div class="example">

``` example
find / -owner OLDUSER -print0 | xargs -0 chown -h NEWUSER
```

</div>

But that is dangerous because the interval between when the `find` tests
the existing file’s owner and when the `chown` is actually run may be
quite large. One way to narrow the gap would be to invoke chown for each
file as it is found:

<div class="example">

``` example
find / -owner OLDUSER -exec chown -h NEWUSER {} \;
```

</div>

But that is very slow if there are many affected files. With this
option, it is safer (the gap is narrower still) though still not
perfect:

<div class="example">

``` example
chown -h -R --from=OLDUSER NEWUSER /
```

</div>

‘`--dereference`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002ddereference-2"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-links_002c-changing-owner-1"></span> <span
id="index-lchown"></span>

Do not act on symbolic links themselves but rather on what they point
to. This is the default when not operating recursively.

Combining this dereferencing option with the `--recursive` option may
create a security risk: During the traversal of the directory tree, an
attacker may be able to introduce a symlink to an arbitrary target; when
the tool reaches that, the operation will be performed on the target of
that symlink, possibly allowing the attacker to escalate privileges.

‘`-h`’  
‘`--no-dereference`’  
<span id="index-_002dh-5"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dno_002ddereference-2"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-links_002c-changing-owner-2"></span> <span
id="index-lchown-1"></span>

Act on symbolic links themselves instead of what they point to. This
mode relies on the `lchown` system call. On systems that do not provide
the `lchown` system call, `chown` fails when a file specified on the
command line is a symbolic link. By default, no diagnostic is issued for
symbolic links encountered during a recursive traversal, but see
`--verbose`.

‘`--preserve-root`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dpreserve_002droot-1"></span> <span
id="index-root-directory_002c-disallow-recursive-modification"></span>

Fail upon any attempt to recursively change the root directory, `/`.
Without `--recursive`, this option has no effect. See [Treating /
specially](#Treating-_002f-specially).

‘`--no-preserve-root`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dno_002dpreserve_002droot-1"></span> <span
id="index-root-directory_002c-allow-recursive-modification"></span>

Cancel the effect of any preceding `--preserve-root` option. See
[Treating / specially](#Treating-_002f-specially).

‘`--reference=ref_file`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dreference"></span>

Change the user and group of each `file` to be the same as those of
`ref_file`. If `ref_file` is a symbolic link, do not use the user and
group of the symbolic link, but rather those of the file it refers to.

‘`-v`’  
‘`--verbose`’  
<span id="index-_002dv-16"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dverbose-12"></span>

Output a diagnostic for every file processed. If a symbolic link is
encountered during a recursive traversal on a system without the
`lchown` system call, and `--no-dereference` is in effect, then issue a
diagnostic saying neither the symbolic link nor its referent is being
changed.

‘`-R`’  
‘`--recursive`’  
<span id="index-_002dR-5"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002drecursive-3"></span> <span
id="index-recursively-changing-file-ownership"></span>

Recursively change ownership of directories and their contents.

‘`-H`’  
<span id="index-_002dH-3"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-traverse-if-on-the-command-line-1"></span>

If `--recursive` (`-R`) is specified and a command line argument is a
symbolic link to a directory, traverse it. See [Traversing
symlinks](#Traversing-symlinks).

‘`-L`’  
<span id="index-_002dL-5"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-traverse-each-that-is-encountered-1"></span>

In a recursive traversal, traverse every symbolic link to a directory
that is encountered.

Combining this dereferencing option with the `--recursive` option may
create a security risk: During the traversal of the directory tree, an
attacker may be able to introduce a symlink to an arbitrary target; when
the tool reaches that, the operation will be performed on the target of
that symlink, possibly allowing the attacker to escalate privileges.

See [Traversing symlinks](#Traversing-symlinks).

‘`-P`’  
<span id="index-_002dP-3"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-never-traverse-1"></span>

Do not traverse any symbolic links. This is the default if none of `-H`,
`-L`, or `-P` is specified. See [Traversing
symlinks](#Traversing-symlinks).

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

Examples:

<div class="example">

``` example
# Change the owner of /u to "root".
chown root /u

# Likewise, but also change its group to "staff".
chown root:staff /u

# Change the owner of /u and subfiles to "root".
chown -hR root /u
```

</div>

<span id="chgrp_003a-Change-group-ownership"></span>

### 13.2 `chgrp`: Change group ownership

<span id="index-chgrp"></span> <span
id="index-group-ownership_002c-changing-1"></span> <span
id="index-changing-group-ownership-1"></span>

`chgrp` changes the group ownership of each given `file` to `group`
(which can be either a group name or a numeric group ID) or to the group
of an existing reference file. See [chown
invocation](#chown-invocation). Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
chgrp [option]… {group | --reference=ref_file} file…
```

</div>

If `group` is intended to represent a numeric group ID, then you may
specify it with a leading ‘`+`’. See [Disambiguating names and
IDs](#Disambiguating-names-and-IDs).

It is system dependent whether a user can change the group to an
arbitrary one, or the more portable behavior of being restricted to
setting a group of which the user is a member.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-c`’  
‘`--changes`’  
<span id="index-_002dc-16"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dchanges-1"></span> <span
id="index-changed-files_002c-verbosely-describing"></span>

Verbosely describe the action for each `file` whose group actually
changes.

‘`-f`’  
‘`--silent`’  
‘`--quiet`’  
<span id="index-_002df-17"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dsilent-5"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dquiet-6"></span> <span
id="index-error-messages_002c-omitting-1"></span>

Do not print error messages about files whose group cannot be changed.

‘`--dereference`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002ddereference-3"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-links_002c-changing-owner-3"></span> <span
id="index-lchown-2"></span>

Do not act on symbolic links themselves but rather on what they point
to. This is the default when not operating recursively.

Combining this dereferencing option with the `--recursive` option may
create a security risk: During the traversal of the directory tree, an
attacker may be able to introduce a symlink to an arbitrary target; when
the tool reaches that, the operation will be performed on the target of
that symlink, possibly allowing the attacker to escalate privileges.

‘`-h`’  
‘`--no-dereference`’  
<span id="index-_002dh-6"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dno_002ddereference-3"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-links_002c-changing-group"></span> <span
id="index-lchown-3"></span>

Act on symbolic links themselves instead of what they point to. This
mode relies on the `lchown` system call. On systems that do not provide
the `lchown` system call, `chgrp` fails when a file specified on the
command line is a symbolic link. By default, no diagnostic is issued for
symbolic links encountered during a recursive traversal, but see
`--verbose`.

‘`--preserve-root`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dpreserve_002droot-2"></span> <span
id="index-root-directory_002c-disallow-recursive-modification-1"></span>

Fail upon any attempt to recursively change the root directory, `/`.
Without `--recursive`, this option has no effect. See [Treating /
specially](#Treating-_002f-specially).

‘`--no-preserve-root`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dno_002dpreserve_002droot-2"></span> <span
id="index-root-directory_002c-allow-recursive-modification-1"></span>

Cancel the effect of any preceding `--preserve-root` option. See
[Treating / specially](#Treating-_002f-specially).

‘`--reference=ref_file`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dreference-1"></span>

Change the group of each `file` to be the same as that of `ref_file`. If
`ref_file` is a symbolic link, do not use the group of the symbolic
link, but rather that of the file it refers to.

‘`-v`’  
‘`--verbose`’  
<span id="index-_002dv-17"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dverbose-13"></span>

Output a diagnostic for every file processed. If a symbolic link is
encountered during a recursive traversal on a system without the
`lchown` system call, and `--no-dereference` is in effect, then issue a
diagnostic saying neither the symbolic link nor its referent is being
changed.

‘`-R`’  
‘`--recursive`’  
<span id="index-_002dR-6"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002drecursive-4"></span> <span
id="index-recursively-changing-group-ownership"></span>

Recursively change the group ownership of directories and their
contents.

‘`-H`’  
<span id="index-_002dH-4"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-traverse-if-on-the-command-line-2"></span>

If `--recursive` (`-R`) is specified and a command line argument is a
symbolic link to a directory, traverse it. See [Traversing
symlinks](#Traversing-symlinks).

‘`-L`’  
<span id="index-_002dL-6"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-traverse-each-that-is-encountered-2"></span>

In a recursive traversal, traverse every symbolic link to a directory
that is encountered.

Combining this dereferencing option with the `--recursive` option may
create a security risk: During the traversal of the directory tree, an
attacker may be able to introduce a symlink to an arbitrary target; when
the tool reaches that, the operation will be performed on the target of
that symlink, possibly allowing the attacker to escalate privileges.

See [Traversing symlinks](#Traversing-symlinks).

‘`-P`’  
<span id="index-_002dP-4"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-link-to-directory_002c-never-traverse-2"></span>

Do not traverse any symbolic links. This is the default if none of `-H`,
`-L`, or `-P` is specified. See [Traversing
symlinks](#Traversing-symlinks).

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

Examples:

<div class="example">

``` example
# Change the group of /u to "staff".
chgrp staff /u

# Change the group of /u and subfiles to "staff".
chgrp -hR staff /u
```

</div>

<span id="chmod_003a-Change-access-permissions"></span>

### 13.3 `chmod`: Change access permissions

<span id="index-chmod"></span> <span
id="index-changing-access-permissions"></span> <span
id="index-access-permissions_002c-changing"></span> <span
id="index-permissions_002c-changing-access"></span>

`chmod` changes the access permissions of the named files. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
chmod [option]… {mode | --reference=ref_file} file…
```

</div>

<span id="index-symbolic-links_002c-permissions-of"></span>

`chmod` never changes the permissions of symbolic links, since the
`chmod` system call cannot change their permissions. This is not a
problem since the permissions of symbolic links are never used. However,
for each symbolic link listed on the command line, `chmod` changes the
permissions of the pointed-to file. In contrast, `chmod` ignores
symbolic links encountered during recursive directory traversals.

Only a process whose effective user ID matches the user ID of the file,
or a process with appropriate privileges, is permitted to change the
file mode bits of a file.

A successful use of `chmod` clears the set-group-ID bit of a regular
file if the file’s group ID does not match the user’s effective group ID
or one of the user’s supplementary group IDs, unless the user has
appropriate privileges. Additional restrictions may cause the
set-user-ID and set-group-ID bits of `mode` or `ref_file` to be ignored.
This behavior depends on the policy and functionality of the underlying
`chmod` system call. When in doubt, check the underlying system
behavior.

If used, `mode` specifies the new file mode bits. For details, see the
section on [File permissions](#File-permissions). If you really want
`mode` to have a leading ‘`-`’, you should use `--` first, e.g.,
‘`chmod -- -w file`’. Typically, though, ‘`chmod a-w file`’ is
preferable, and `chmod -w file` (without the `--`) complains if it
behaves differently from what ‘`chmod a-w file`’ would do.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-c`’  
‘`--changes`’  
<span id="index-_002dc-17"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dchanges-2"></span>

Verbosely describe the action for each `file` whose permissions actually
change.

‘`-f`’  
‘`--silent`’  
‘`--quiet`’  
<span id="index-_002df-18"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dsilent-6"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dquiet-7"></span> <span
id="index-error-messages_002c-omitting-2"></span>

Do not print error messages about files whose permissions cannot be
changed.

‘`--preserve-root`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dpreserve_002droot-3"></span> <span
id="index-root-directory_002c-disallow-recursive-modification-2"></span>

Fail upon any attempt to recursively change the root directory, `/`.
Without `--recursive`, this option has no effect. See [Treating /
specially](#Treating-_002f-specially).

‘`--no-preserve-root`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dno_002dpreserve_002droot-3"></span> <span
id="index-root-directory_002c-allow-recursive-modification-2"></span>

Cancel the effect of any preceding `--preserve-root` option. See
[Treating / specially](#Treating-_002f-specially).

‘`-v`’  
‘`--verbose`’  
<span id="index-_002dv-18"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dverbose-14"></span>

Verbosely describe the action or non-action taken for every `file`.

‘`--reference=ref_file`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dreference-2"></span>

Change the mode of each `file` to be the same as that of `ref_file`. See
[File permissions](#File-permissions). If `ref_file` is a symbolic link,
do not use the mode of the symbolic link, but rather that of the file it
refers to.

‘`-R`’  
‘`--recursive`’  
<span id="index-_002dR-7"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002drecursive-5"></span> <span
id="index-recursively-changing-access-permissions"></span>

Recursively change permissions of directories and their contents.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

Examples:

<div class="example">

``` example
# Change file permissions of FOO to be world readable
# and user writable, with no other permissions.
chmod 644 foo
chmod a=r,u+w foo

# Add user and group execute permissions to FOO.
chmod +110 file
chmod ug+x file

# Set file permissions of DIR and subsidiary files to
# be the umask default, assuming execute permissions for
# directories and for files already executable.
chmod -R a=,+rwX dir
```

</div>

<span id="touch_003a-Change-file-timestamps"></span>

### 13.4 `touch`: Change file timestamps

<span id="index-touch"></span> <span
id="index-changing-file-timestamps"></span> <span
id="index-file-timestamps_002c-changing"></span> <span
id="index-timestamps_002c-changing-file"></span>

`touch` changes the access and/or modification timestamps of the
specified files. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
touch [option]… file…
```

</div>

<span id="index-empty-files_002c-creating"></span>

Any `file` argument that does not exist is created empty, unless option
`--no-create` (`-c`) or `--no-dereference` (`-h`) was in effect.

A `file` argument string of ‘`-`’ is handled specially and causes
`touch` to change the times of the file associated with standard output.

By default, `touch` sets file timestamps to the current time. Because
`touch` acts on its operands left to right, the resulting timestamps of
earlier and later operands may disagree.

<span id="index-permissions_002c-for-changing-file-timestamps"></span>

When setting file timestamps to the current time, `touch` can change the
timestamps for files that the user does not own but has write permission
for. Otherwise, the user must own the files. Some older systems have a
further restriction: the user must own the files unless both the access
and modification timestamps are being set to the current time.

The `touch` command cannot set a file’s status change timestamp to a
user-specified value, and cannot change the file’s birth time (if
supported) at all. Also, `touch` has issues similar to those affecting
all programs that update file timestamps. For example, `touch` may set a
file’s timestamp to a value that differs slightly from the requested
time. See [File timestamps](#File-timestamps).

<span id="index-TZ-2"></span>

Timestamps assume the time zone rules specified by the `TZ` environment
variable, or by the system default rules if `TZ` is not set. See
[Specifying the Time Zone with
`TZ`](https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#TZ-Variable)
in The GNU C Library Reference Manual. You can avoid ambiguities during
daylight saving transitions by using UTC timestamps.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-a`’  
‘`--time=atime`’  
‘`--time=access`’  
‘`--time=use`’  
<span id="index-_002da-8"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dtime-3"></span> <span
id="index-atime_002c-changing"></span> <span
id="index-access-time_002c-changing"></span> <span
id="index-use-time_002c-changing"></span>

Change the access timestamp only. See [File
timestamps](#File-timestamps).

‘`-c`’  
‘`--no-create`’  
<span id="index-_002dc-18"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dno_002dcreate"></span>

Do not warn about or create files that do not exist.

‘`-d time`’  
‘`--date=time`’  
<span id="index-_002dd-15"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002ddate"></span> <span id="index-time"></span>

Use `time` instead of the current time. It can contain month names, time
zones, ‘`am`’ and ‘`pm`’, ‘`yesterday`’, etc. For example,
`--date="2020-07-21 14:19:13.489392193 +0530"` specifies the instant of
time that is 489,392,193 nanoseconds after July 21, 2020 at 2:19:13 PM
in a time zone that is 5 hours and 30 minutes east of UTC. See [Date
input formats](#Date-input-formats). File systems that do not support
high-resolution timestamps silently ignore any excess precision here.

‘`-f`’  
<span id="index-_002df-19"></span> <span
id="index-BSD-touch-compatibility"></span>

Ignored; for compatibility with BSD versions of `touch`.

‘`-h`’  
‘`--no-dereference`’  
<span id="index-_002dh-7"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dno_002ddereference-4"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-links_002c-changing-time"></span> <span
id="index-lutimes"></span>

Attempt to change the timestamps of a symbolic link, rather than what
the link refers to. When using this option, empty files are not created,
but option `-c` must also be used to avoid warning about files that do
not exist. Not all systems support changing the timestamps of symlinks,
since underlying system support for this action was not required until
POSIX 2008. Also, on some systems, the mere act of examining a symbolic
link changes the access timestamp, such that only changes to the
modification timestamp will persist long enough to be observable. When
coupled with option `-r`, a reference timestamp is taken from a symbolic
link rather than the file it refers to.

‘`-m`’  
‘`--time=mtime`’  
‘`--time=modify`’  
<span id="index-_002dm-9"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dtime-4"></span> <span
id="index-mtime_002c-changing"></span> <span
id="index-modify-time_002c-changing"></span>

Change the modification timestamp only.

‘`-r file`’  
‘`--reference=file`’  
<span id="index-_002dr-10"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dreference-3"></span>

Use the times of the reference `file` instead of the current time. If
this option is combined with the `--date=time` (`-d time`) option, the
reference `file`’s time is the origin for any relative `time`s given,
but is otherwise ignored. For example, ‘`-r foo -d '-5 seconds'`’
specifies a timestamp equal to five seconds before the corresponding
timestamp for `foo`. If `file` is a symbolic link, the reference
timestamp is taken from the target of the symlink, unless `-h` was also
in effect.

‘`-t [[cc]yy]mmddhhmm[.ss]`’  
<span id="index-leap-seconds"></span>

Use the argument (optional four-digit or two-digit years, months, days,
hours, minutes, optional seconds) instead of the current time. If the
year is specified with only two digits, then `cc` is 20 for years in the
range 0 … 68, and 19 for years in 69 … 99. If no digits of the year are
specified, the argument is interpreted as a date in the current year. On
the atypical systems that support leap seconds, `ss` may be ‘`60`’.

<span id="index-_005fPOSIX2_005fVERSION-4"></span>

On systems predating POSIX 1003.1-2001, `touch` supports an obsolete
syntax, as follows. If no timestamp is given with any of the `-d`, `-r`,
or `-t` options, and if there are two or more `file`s and the first
`file` is of the form ‘`mmddhhmm[yy]`’ and this would be a valid
argument to the `-t` option (if the `yy`, if any, were moved to the
front), and if the represented year is in the range 1969–1999, that
argument is interpreted as the time for the other files instead of as a
file name. Although this obsolete behavior can be controlled with the
`_POSIX2_VERSION` environment variable (see [Standards
conformance](#Standards-conformance)), portable scripts should avoid
commands whose behavior depends on this variable. For example, use
‘`touch ./12312359 main.c`’ or ‘`touch -t 12312359 main.c`’ rather than
the ambiguous ‘`touch 12312359 main.c`’.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span id="File-space-usage-1"></span>

## 14 File space usage

<span id="index-File-space-usage"></span> <span
id="index-disk-usage"></span>

No file system can hold an infinite amount of data. These commands
report how much storage is in use or available, report other file and
file status information, and write buffers to file systems.

|                                                                        |     |                                                  |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------------|-----|:-------------------------------------------------|
| • <a href="#df-invocation" accesskey="1">df invocation</a>             |     | Report file system space usage.                  |
| • <a href="#du-invocation" accesskey="2">du invocation</a>             |     | Estimate file space usage.                       |
| • <a href="#stat-invocation" accesskey="3">stat invocation</a>         |     | Report file or file system status.               |
| • <a href="#sync-invocation" accesskey="4">sync invocation</a>         |     | Synchronize cached writes to persistent storage. |
| • <a href="#truncate-invocation" accesskey="5">truncate invocation</a> |     | Shrink or extend the size of a file.             |

<span id="df_003a-Report-file-system-space-usage"></span>

### 14.1 `df`: Report file system space usage

<span id="index-df"></span> <span id="index-file-system-usage"></span>
<span id="index-disk-usage-by-file-system"></span>

`df` reports the amount of space used and available on file systems.
Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
df [option]… [file]…
```

</div>

With no arguments, `df` reports the space used and available on all
currently mounted file systems (of all types). Otherwise, `df` reports
on the file system containing each argument `file`.

Normally the space is printed in units of 1024 bytes, but this can be
overridden (see [Block size](#Block-size)). Non-integer quantities are
rounded up to the next higher unit.

For bind mounts and without arguments, `df` only outputs the statistics
for that device with the shortest mount point name in the list of file
systems (`mtab`), i.e., it hides duplicate entries, unless the `-a`
option is specified.

With the same logic, `df` elides a mount entry of a dummy pseudo device
if there is another mount entry of a real block device for that mount
point with the same device number, e.g. the early-boot pseudo file
system ‘`rootfs`’ is not shown per default when already the real root
device has been mounted.

<span id="index-disk-device-file"></span> <span
id="index-device-file"></span>

If an argument `file` resolves to a special file containing a mounted
file system, `df` shows the space available on that file system rather
than on the file system containing the device node. GNU `df` does not
attempt to determine the usage on unmounted file systems, because on
most kinds of systems doing so requires extremely nonportable intimate
knowledge of file system structures.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-a`’  
‘`--all`’  
<span id="index-_002da-9"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dall-2"></span> <span
id="index-ignore-file-systems"></span>

Include in the listing dummy, duplicate, or inaccessible file systems,
which are omitted by default. Dummy file systems are typically special
purpose pseudo file systems such as ‘`/proc`’, with no associated
storage. Duplicate file systems are local or remote file systems that
are mounted at separate locations in the local file hierarchy, or bind
mounted locations. Inaccessible file systems are those which are mounted
but subsequently over-mounted by another file system at that point, or
otherwise inaccessible due to permissions of the mount point etc.

‘`-B size`’  
‘`--block-size=size`’  
<span id="index-_002dB-1"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dblock_002dsize-1"></span> <span
id="index-file-system-sizes"></span>

Scale sizes by `size` before printing them (see [Block
size](#Block-size)). For example, `-BG` prints sizes in units of
1,073,741,824 bytes.

‘`-h`’  
‘`--human-readable`’  
<span id="index-_002dh-8"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dhuman_002dreadable-2"></span> <span
id="index-human_002dreadable-output-2"></span>

Append a size letter to each size, such as ‘`M`’ for mebibytes. Powers
of 1024 are used, not 1000; ‘`M`’ stands for 1,048,576 bytes. This
option is equivalent to `--block-size=human-readable`. Use the `--si`
option if you prefer powers of 1000.

‘`-H`’  
<span id="index-_002dH-5"></span>

Equivalent to `--si`.

‘`-i`’  
‘`--inodes`’  
<span id="index-_002di-15"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dinodes"></span> <span id="index-inode-usage"></span>

List inode usage information instead of block usage. An inode (short for
index node) contains information about a file such as its owner,
permissions, timestamps, and location on the file system.

‘`-k`’  
<span id="index-_002dk-4"></span> <span
id="index-kibibytes-for-file-system-sizes"></span>

Print sizes in 1024-byte blocks, overriding the default block size (see
[Block size](#Block-size)). This option is equivalent to
`--block-size=1K`.

‘`-l`’  
‘`--local`’  
<span id="index-_002dl-8"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dlocal"></span> <span
id="index-file-system-types_002c-limiting-output-to-certain"></span>

Limit the listing to local file systems. By default, remote file systems
are also listed.

‘`--no-sync`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dno_002dsync"></span> <span
id="index-file-system-space_002c-retrieving-old-data-more-quickly"></span>

Do not invoke the `sync` system call before getting any usage data. This
may make `df` run significantly faster on systems with many file
systems, but on some systems (notably Solaris) the results may be
slightly out of date. This is the default.

‘`--output`’  
‘`--output[=field_list]`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002doutput-2"></span>

Use the output format defined by `field_list`, or print all fields if
`field_list` is omitted. In the latter case, the order of the columns
conforms to the order of the field descriptions below.

The use of the `--output` together with each of the options `-i`, `-P`,
and `-T` is mutually exclusive.

FIELD_LIST is a comma-separated list of columns to be included in `df`’s
output and therefore effectively controls the order of output columns.
Each field can thus be used at the place of choice, but yet must only be
used once.

Valid field names in the `field_list` are:

‘`source`’  
The source of the mount point, usually a device.

‘`fstype`’  
File system type.

‘`itotal`’  
Total number of inodes.

‘`iused`’  
Number of used inodes.

‘`iavail`’  
Number of available inodes.

‘`ipcent`’  
Percentage of `iused` divided by `itotal`.

‘`size`’  
Total number of blocks.

‘`used`’  
Number of used blocks.

‘`avail`’  
Number of available blocks.

‘`pcent`’  
Percentage of `used` divided by `size`.

‘`file`’  
The file name if specified on the command line.

‘`target`’  
The mount point.

The fields for block and inodes statistics are affected by the scaling
options like `-h` as usual.

The definition of the `field_list` can even be split among several
`--output` uses.

<div class="example">

``` example
#!/bin/sh
# Print the TARGET (i.e., the mount point) along with their percentage
# statistic regarding the blocks and the inodes.
df --out=target --output=pcent,ipcent

# Print all available fields.
df --o
```

</div>

‘`-P`’  
‘`--portability`’  
<span id="index-_002dP-5"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dportability"></span> <span
id="index-one_002dline-output-format"></span> <span
id="index-POSIX-output-format"></span> <span
id="index-portable-output-format"></span> <span
id="index-output-format_002c-portable"></span>

Use the POSIX output format. This is like the default format except for
the following:

1.  The information about each file system is always printed on exactly
    one line; a mount device is never put on a line by itself. This
    means that if the mount device name is more than 20 characters long
    (e.g., for some network mounts), the columns are misaligned.
2.  The labels in the header output line are changed to conform to
    POSIX.
3.  The default block size and output format are unaffected by the
    `DF_BLOCK_SIZE`, `BLOCK_SIZE` and `BLOCKSIZE` environment variables.
    However, the default block size is still affected by
    `POSIXLY_CORRECT`: it is 512 if `POSIXLY_CORRECT` is set, 1024
    otherwise. See [Block size](#Block-size).

‘`--si`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dsi-2"></span> <span
id="index-SI-output-2"></span>

Append an SI-style abbreviation to each size, such as ‘`M`’ for
megabytes. Powers of 1000 are used, not 1024; ‘`M`’ stands for 1,000,000
bytes. This option is equivalent to `--block-size=si`. Use the `-h` or
`--human-readable` option if you prefer powers of 1024.

‘`--sync`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dsync"></span> <span
id="index-file-system-space_002c-retrieving-current-data-more-slowly"></span>

Invoke the `sync` system call before getting any usage data. On some
systems (notably Solaris), doing this yields more up to date results,
but in general this option makes `df` much slower, especially when there
are many or very busy file systems.

‘`--total`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dtotal"></span> <span
id="index-grand-total-of-file-system-size_002c-usage-and-available-space"></span>

Print a grand total of all arguments after all arguments have been
processed. This can be used to find out the total size, usage and
available space of all listed devices. If no arguments are specified df
will try harder to elide file systems insignificant to the total
available space, by suppressing duplicate remote file systems.

For the grand total line, `df` prints ‘`"total"`’ into the `source`
column, and ‘`"-"`’ into the `target` column. If there is no `source`
column (see `--output`), then `df` prints ‘`"total"`’ into the `target`
column, if present.

‘`-t fstype`’  
‘`--type=fstype`’  
<span id="index-_002dt-15"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dtype"></span> <span
id="index-file-system-types_002c-limiting-output-to-certain-1"></span>

Limit the listing to file systems of type `fstype`. Multiple file system
types can be specified by giving multiple `-t` options. By default,
nothing is omitted.

‘`-T`’  
‘`--print-type`’  
<span id="index-_002dT-9"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dprint_002dtype"></span> <span
id="index-file-system-types_002c-printing"></span>

Print each file system’s type. The types printed here are the same ones
you can include or exclude with `-t` and `-x`. The particular types
printed are whatever is supported by the system. Here are some of the
common names (this list is certainly not exhaustive):

‘`nfs`’  
<span id="index-NFS-file-system-type"></span>

An NFS file system, i.e., one mounted over a network from another
machine. This is the one type name which seems to be used uniformly by
all systems.

‘`ext2, ext3, ext4, xfs, btrfs…`’  
<span id="index-Linux-file-system-types"></span> <span
id="index-local-file-system-types"></span> <span
id="index-ext2-file-system-type"></span> <span
id="index-ext3-file-system-type"></span> <span
id="index-ext4-file-system-type"></span> <span
id="index-xfs-file-system-type"></span> <span
id="index-btrfs-file-system-type"></span>

A file system on a locally-mounted device. (The system might even
support more than one type here; GNU/Linux does.)

‘`iso9660, cdfs`’  
<span id="index-CD_002dROM-file-system-type"></span> <span
id="index-DVD-file-system-type"></span> <span
id="index-ISO9660-file-system-type"></span> <span
id="index-iso9660-file-system-type"></span> <span
id="index-cdfs-file-system-type"></span>

A file system on a CD or DVD drive. HP-UX uses ‘`cdfs`’, most other
systems use ‘`iso9660`’.

‘`ntfs,fat`’  
<span id="index-NTFS-file-system"></span> <span
id="index-DOS-file-system"></span> <span
id="index-MS_002dDOS-file-system"></span> <span
id="index-MS_002dWindows-file-system"></span> <span
id="index-ntfs-file-system-file"></span> <span
id="index-fat-file-system-file"></span>

File systems used by MS-Windows / MS-DOS.

‘`-x fstype`’  
‘`--exclude-type=fstype`’  
<span id="index-_002dx-5"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dexclude_002dtype"></span>

Limit the listing to file systems not of type `fstype`. Multiple file
system types can be eliminated by giving multiple `-x` options. By
default, no file system types are omitted.

‘`-v`’  
Ignored; for compatibility with System V versions of `df`.

`df` is installed only on systems that have usable mount tables, so
portable scripts should not rely on its existence.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure. Failure includes the case where no output is generated, so you
can inspect the exit status of a command like
‘`df -t ext3 -t reiserfs dir`’ to test whether `dir` is on a file system
of type ‘`ext3`’ or ‘`reiserfs`’.

Since the list of file systems (`mtab`) is needed to determine the file
system type, failure includes the cases when that list cannot be read
and one or more of the options `-a`, `-l`, `-t` or `-x` is used together
with a file name argument.
