<span id="du_003a-Estimate-file-space-usage"></span>

### 14.2 `du`: Estimate file space usage

<span id="index-du"></span> <span id="index-file-space-usage"></span>
<span id="index-disk-usage-for-files"></span>

`du` reports the amount of file system space used by the set of
specified files and for each subdirectory (of directory arguments).
Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
du [option]… [file]…
```

</div>

With no arguments, `du` reports the file system space for the current
directory. Normally the space is printed in units of 1024 bytes, but
this can be overridden (see [Block size](#Block-size)). Non-integer
quantities are rounded up to the next higher unit.

If two or more hard links point to the same file, only one of the hard
links is counted. The `file` argument order affects which links are
counted, and changing the argument order may change the numbers and
entries that `du` outputs.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-0`’  
‘`--null`’  
<span id="index-_002d0"></span> <span id="index-_002d_002dnull"></span>
<span id="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines-3"></span>

Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line, rather than a
newline. This option enables other programs to parse the output even
when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.

‘`-a`’  
‘`--all`’  
<span id="index-_002da-10"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dall-3"></span>

Show counts for all files, not just directories.

‘`--apparent-size`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dapparent_002dsize"></span>

Print apparent sizes, rather than file system usage. The apparent size
of a file is the number of bytes reported by `wc -c` on regular files,
or more generally, `ls -l --block-size=1` or `stat --format=%s`. For
example, a file containing the word ‘`zoo`’ with no newline would, of
course, have an apparent size of 3. Such a small file may require
anywhere from 0 to 16 KiB or more of file system space, depending on the
type and configuration of the file system on which the file resides.
However, a sparse file created with this command:

<div class="example">

``` example
dd bs=1 seek=2GiB if=/dev/null of=big
```

</div>

has an apparent size of 2 GiB, yet on most modern file systems, it
actually uses almost no space.

‘`-B size`’  
‘`--block-size=size`’  
<span id="index-_002dB-2"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dblock_002dsize-2"></span> <span
id="index-file-sizes"></span>

Scale sizes by `size` before printing them (see [Block
size](#Block-size)). For example, `-BG` prints sizes in units of
1,073,741,824 bytes.

‘`-b`’  
‘`--bytes`’  
<span id="index-_002db-18"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dbytes-6"></span>

Equivalent to `--apparent-size --block-size=1`.

‘`-c`’  
‘`--total`’  
<span id="index-_002dc-19"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dtotal-1"></span> <span
id="index-grand-total-of-file-system-space"></span>

Print a grand total of all arguments after all arguments have been
processed. This can be used to find out the total file system usage of a
given set of files or directories.

‘`-D`’  
‘`--dereference-args`’  
<span id="index-_002dD-3"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002ddereference_002dargs"></span>

Dereference symbolic links that are command line arguments. Does not
affect other symbolic links. This is helpful for finding out the file
system usage of directories, such as `/usr/tmp`, which are often
symbolic links.

‘`-d depth`’  
‘`--max-depth=depth`’  
<span id="index-_002dd-depth"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dmax_002ddepth_003ddepth"></span> <span
id="index-limiting-output-of-du"></span>

Show the total for each directory (and file if –all) that is at most
MAX_DEPTH levels down from the root of the hierarchy. The root is at
level 0, so `du --max-depth=0` is equivalent to `du -s`.

‘`--files0-from=file`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dfiles0_002dfrom_003dfile-2"></span>

Disallow processing files named on the command line, and instead process
those named in file `file`; each name being terminated by a zero byte
(ASCII NUL). This is useful when the list of file names is so long that
it may exceed a command line length limitation. In such cases, running
`du` via `xargs` is undesirable because it splits the list into pieces
and makes `du` print with the `--total` (`-c`) option for each sublist
rather than for the entire list. One way to produce a list of ASCII NUL
terminated file names is with GNU `find`, using its `-print0` predicate.
If `file` is ‘`-`’ then the ASCII NUL terminated file names are read
from standard input.

‘`-H`’  
<span id="index-_002dH-6"></span>

Equivalent to `--dereference-args` (`-D`).

‘`-h`’  
‘`--human-readable`’  
<span id="index-_002dh-9"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dhuman_002dreadable-3"></span> <span
id="index-human_002dreadable-output-3"></span>

Append a size letter to each size, such as ‘`M`’ for mebibytes. Powers
of 1024 are used, not 1000; ‘`M`’ stands for 1,048,576 bytes. This
option is equivalent to `--block-size=human-readable`. Use the `--si`
option if you prefer powers of 1000.

‘`--inodes`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dinodes-1"></span> <span
id="index-inode-usage_002c-dereferencing-in-du"></span>

List inode usage information instead of block usage. This option is
useful for finding directories which contain many files, and therefore
eat up most of the inodes space of a file system (see `df`, option
`--inodes`). It can well be combined with the options `-a`, `-c`, `-h`,
`-l`, `-s`, `-S`, `-t` and `-x`; however, passing other options
regarding the block size, for example `-b`, `-m` and `--apparent-size`,
is ignored.

‘`-k`’  
<span id="index-_002dk-5"></span> <span
id="index-kibibytes-for-file-sizes"></span>

Print sizes in 1024-byte blocks, overriding the default block size (see
[Block size](#Block-size)). This option is equivalent to
`--block-size=1K`.

‘`-L`’  
‘`--dereference`’  
<span id="index-_002dL-7"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002ddereference-4"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-links_002c-dereferencing-in-du"></span>

Dereference symbolic links (show the file system space used by the file
or directory that the link points to instead of the space used by the
link).

‘`-l`’  
‘`--count-links`’  
<span id="index-_002dl-9"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dcount_002dlinks"></span> <span
id="index-hard-links_002c-counting-in-du"></span>

Count the size of all files, even if they have appeared already (as a
hard link).

‘`-m`’  
<span id="index-_002dm-10"></span> <span
id="index-mebibytes-for-file-sizes"></span>

Print sizes in 1,048,576-byte blocks, overriding the default block size
(see [Block size](#Block-size)). This option is equivalent to
`--block-size=1M`.

‘`-P`’  
‘`--no-dereference`’  
<span id="index-_002dP-6"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dno_002ddereference-5"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-links_002c-dereferencing-in-du-1"></span>

For each symbolic link encountered by `du`, consider the file system
space used by the symbolic link itself.

‘`-S`’  
‘`--separate-dirs`’  
<span id="index-_002dS-10"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dseparate_002ddirs"></span>

Normally, in the output of `du` (when not using `--summarize`), the size
listed next to a directory name, `d`, represents the sum of sizes of all
entries beneath `d` as well as the size of `d` itself. With
`--separate-dirs`, the size reported for a directory name, `d`, will
exclude the size of any subdirectories.

‘`--si`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dsi-3"></span> <span
id="index-SI-output-3"></span>

Append an SI-style abbreviation to each size, such as ‘`M`’ for
megabytes. Powers of 1000 are used, not 1024; ‘`M`’ stands for 1,000,000
bytes. This option is equivalent to `--block-size=si`. Use the `-h` or
`--human-readable` option if you prefer powers of 1024.

‘`-s`’  
‘`--summarize`’  
<span id="index-_002ds-20"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dsummarize"></span>

Display only a total for each argument.

‘`-t size`’  
‘`--threshold=size`’  
<span id="index-_002dt-16"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dthreshold"></span>

Exclude entries based on a given `size`. The `size` refers to used
blocks in normal mode (see [Block size](#Block-size)), or inodes count
in conjunction with the `--inodes` option.

If `size` is positive, then `du` will only print entries with a size
greater than or equal to that.

If `size` is negative, then `du` will only print entries with a size
smaller than or equal to that.

Although GNU `find` can be used to find files of a certain size, `du`’s
`--threshold` option can be used to also filter directories based on a
given size.

Please note that the `--threshold` option can be combined with the
`--apparent-size` option, and in this case would elide entries based on
its apparent size.

Please note that the `--threshold` option can be combined with the
`--inodes` option, and in this case would elide entries based on its
inodes count.

Here’s how you would use `--threshold` to find directories with a size
greater than or equal to 200 megabytes:

<div class="example">

``` example
du --threshold=200MB
```

</div>

Here’s how you would use `--threshold` to find directories and files -
note the `-a` - with an apparent size smaller than or equal to 500
bytes:

<div class="example">

``` example
du -a -t -500 --apparent-size
```

</div>

Here’s how you would use `--threshold` to find directories on the root
file system with more than 20000 inodes used in the directory tree
below:

<div class="example">

``` example
du --inodes -x --threshold=20000 /
```

</div>

‘`--time`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dtime-5"></span> <span
id="index-last-modified-dates_002c-displaying-in-du"></span>

Show the most recent modification timestamp (mtime) of any file in the
directory, or any of its subdirectories. See [File
timestamps](#File-timestamps).

‘`--time=ctime`’  
‘`--time=status`’  
‘`--time=use`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dtime-6"></span> <span
id="index-ctime_002c-show-the-most-recent"></span> <span
id="index-status-time_002c-show-the-most-recent"></span> <span
id="index-use-time_002c-show-the-most-recent"></span>

Show the most recent status change timestamp (ctime) of any file in the
directory, or any of its subdirectories. See [File
timestamps](#File-timestamps).

‘`--time=atime`’  
‘`--time=access`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dtime-7"></span> <span
id="index-atime_002c-show-the-most-recent"></span> <span
id="index-access-timestamp_002c-show-the-most-recent"></span>

Show the most recent access timestamp (atime) of any file in the
directory, or any of its subdirectories. See [File
timestamps](#File-timestamps).

‘`--time-style=style`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dtime_002dstyle-1"></span> <span
id="index-time-style-1"></span>

List timestamps in style `style`. This option has an effect only if the
`--time` option is also specified. The `style` should be one of the
following:

‘`+format`’  
<span id="index-LC_005fTIME-5"></span>

List timestamps using `format`, where `format` is interpreted like the
format argument of `date` (see [date invocation](#date-invocation)). For
example, `--time-style="+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S"` causes `du` to list
timestamps like ‘`2020-07-21 23:45:56`’. As with `date`, `format`’s
interpretation is affected by the `LC_TIME` locale category.

‘`full-iso`’  
List timestamps in full using ISO 8601-like date, time, and time zone
components with nanosecond precision, e.g.,
‘`2020-07-21 23:45:56.477817180 -0400`’. This style is equivalent to
‘`+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%N %z`’.

‘`long-iso`’  
List ISO 8601 date and time components with minute precision, e.g.,
‘`2020-07-21 23:45`’. These timestamps are shorter than ‘`full-iso`’
timestamps, and are usually good enough for everyday work. This style is
equivalent to ‘`+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M`’.

‘`iso`’  
List ISO 8601 dates for timestamps, e.g., ‘`2020-07-21`’. This style is
equivalent to ‘`+%Y-%m-%d`’.

<span id="index-TIME_005fSTYLE-1"></span>

You can specify the default value of the `--time-style` option with the
environment variable `TIME_STYLE`; if `TIME_STYLE` is not set the
default style is ‘`long-iso`’. For compatibility with `ls`, if
`TIME_STYLE` begins with ‘`+`’ and contains a newline, the newline and
any later characters are ignored; if `TIME_STYLE` begins with ‘`posix-`’
the ‘`posix-`’ is ignored; and if `TIME_STYLE` is ‘`locale`’ it is
ignored.

‘`-X file`’  
‘`--exclude-from=file`’  
<span id="index-_002dX-file"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dexclude_002dfrom_003dfile"></span> <span
id="index-excluding-files-from-du"></span>

Like `--exclude`, except take the patterns to exclude from `file`, one
per line. If `file` is ‘`-`’, take the patterns from standard input.

‘`--exclude=pattern`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dexclude_003dpattern"></span> <span
id="index-excluding-files-from-du-1"></span>

When recursing, skip subdirectories or files matching `pattern`. For
example, `du --exclude='*.o'` excludes files whose names end in ‘`.o`’.

‘`-x`’  
‘`--one-file-system`’  
<span id="index-_002dx-6"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002done_002dfile_002dsystem-2"></span> <span
id="index-one-file-system_002c-restricting-du-to"></span>

Skip directories that are on different file systems from the one that
the argument being processed is on.

<span id="index-NFS-mounts-from-BSD-to-HP_002dUX-1"></span>

On BSD systems, `du` reports sizes that are half the correct values for
files that are NFS-mounted from HP-UX systems. On HP-UX systems, it
reports sizes that are twice the correct values for files that are
NFS-mounted from BSD systems. This is due to a flaw in HP-UX; it also
affects the HP-UX `du` program.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<span id="stat_003a-Report-file-or-file-system-status"></span>

### 14.3 `stat`: Report file or file system status

<span id="index-stat"></span> <span id="index-file-status"></span> <span
id="index-file-system-status"></span>

`stat` displays information about the specified file(s). Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
stat [option]… [file]…
```

</div>

With no option, `stat` reports all information about the given files.
But it also can be used to report the information of the file systems
the given files are located on. If the files are links, `stat` can also
give information about the files the links point to.

<span id="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins-1"></span> <span
id="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with-1"></span>

Due to shell aliases and built-in `stat` functions, using an unadorned
`stat` interactively or in a script may get you different functionality
than that described here. Invoke it via `env` (i.e., `env stat …`) to
avoid interference from the shell.

‘`-L`’  
‘`--dereference`’  
<span id="index-_002dL-8"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002ddereference-5"></span> <span
id="index-symbolic-links_002c-dereferencing-in-stat"></span>

Change how `stat` treats symbolic links. With this option, `stat` acts
on the file referenced by each symbolic link argument. Without it,
`stat` acts on any symbolic link argument directly.

‘`-f`’  
‘`--file-system`’  
<span id="index-_002df-20"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dfile_002dsystem"></span> <span
id="index-file-systems"></span>

Report information about the file systems where the given files are
located instead of information about the files themselves. This option
implies the `-L` option.

‘`--cached=mode`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dcached_003dmode"></span> <span
id="index-attribute-caching"></span>

Control how attributes are read from the file system; if supported by
the system. This allows one to control the trade-off between freshness
and efficiency of attribute access, especially useful with remote file
systems. `mode` can be:

‘`always`’  
Always read the already cached attributes if available.

‘`never`’  
Always sychronize with the latest file system attributes. This also
mounts automounted files.

‘`default`’  
Leave the caching behavior to the underlying file system.

‘`-c`’  
‘`--format=format`’  
<span id="index-_002dc-20"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dformat_003dformat"></span> <span
id="index-output-format"></span>

Use `format` rather than the default format. `format` is automatically
newline-terminated, so running a command like the following with two or
more `file` operands produces a line of output for each operand:

<div class="example">

``` example
$ stat --format=%d:%i / /usr
2050:2
2057:2
```

</div>

‘`--printf=format`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dprintf_003dformat"></span> <span
id="index-output-format-1"></span>

Use `format` rather than the default format. Like `--format`, but
interpret backslash escapes, and do not output a mandatory trailing
newline. If you want a newline, include ‘`\n`’ in the `format`. Here’s
how you would use `--printf` to print the device and inode numbers of
`/` and `/usr`:

<div class="example">

``` example
$ stat --printf='%d:%i\n' / /usr
2050:2
2057:2
```

</div>

‘`-t`’  
‘`--terse`’  
<span id="index-_002dt-17"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dterse"></span> <span id="index-terse-output"></span>

Print the information in terse form, suitable for parsing by other
programs.

The output of the following commands are identical and the `--format`
also identifies the items printed (in fuller form) in the default
format. Note the format string would include another ‘`%C`’ at the end
with an active SELinux security context.

<div class="example">

``` example
$ stat --format="%n %s %b %f %u %g %D %i %h %t %T %X %Y %Z %W %o" ...
$ stat --terse ...
```

</div>

The same illustrating terse output in `--file-system` mode:

<div class="example">

``` example
$ stat -f --format="%n %i %l %t %s %S %b %f %a %c %d" ...
$ stat -f --terse ...
```

</div>

The valid `format` directives for files with `--format` and `--printf`
are:

-   %a - Permission bits in octal (note ‘`#`’ and ‘`0`’ printf flags)
-   %A - Permission bits in symbolic form (similar to `ls -ld`)
-   %b - Number of blocks allocated (see ‘`%B`’)
-   %B - The size in bytes of each block reported by ‘`%b`’
-   %C - The SELinux security context of a file, if available
-   %d - Device number in decimal (st_dev)
-   %D - Device number in hex (st_dev)
-   %Hd - Major device number in decimal
-   %Ld - Minor device number in decimal
-   %f - Raw mode in hex
-   %F - File type
-   %g - Group ID of owner
-   %G - Group name of owner
-   %h - Number of hard links
-   %i - Inode number
-   %m - Mount point (See note below)
-   %n - File name
-   %N - Quoted file name with dereference if symbolic link (see below)
-   %o - Optimal I/O transfer size hint
-   %s - Total size, in bytes
-   %r - Device type in decimal (st_rdev)
-   %R - Device type in hex (st_rdev)
-   %Hr - Major device type in decimal (see below)
-   %Lr - Minor device type in decimal (see below)
-   %t - Major device type in hex (see below)
-   %T - Minor device type in hex (see below)
-   %u - User ID of owner
-   %U - User name of owner
-   %w - Time of file birth, or ‘`-`’ if unknown
-   %W - Time of file birth as seconds since Epoch, or ‘`0`’
-   %x - Time of last access
-   %X - Time of last access as seconds since Epoch
-   %y - Time of last data modification
-   %Y - Time of last data modification as seconds since Epoch
-   %z - Time of last status change
-   %Z - Time of last status change as seconds since Epoch

The ‘`%a`’ format prints the octal mode, and so it is useful to control
the zero padding of the output with the ‘`#`’ and ‘`0`’ printf flags.
For example to pad to at least 3 wide while making larger numbers
unambiguously octal, you can use ‘`%#03a`’.

The ‘`%N`’ format can be set with the environment variable
`QUOTING_STYLE`. If that environment variable is not set, the default
value is ‘`shell-escape-always`’. Valid quoting styles are:

‘`literal`’  
Output strings as-is; this is the same as the `--literal` (`-N`) option.

‘`shell`’  
Quote strings for the shell if they contain shell metacharacters or
would cause ambiguous output. The quoting is suitable for
POSIX-compatible shells like `bash`, but it does not always work for
incompatible shells like `csh`.

‘`shell-always`’  
Quote strings for the shell, even if they would normally not require
quoting.

‘`shell-escape`’  
Like ‘`shell`’, but also quoting non-printable characters using the
POSIX proposed ‘`$''`’ syntax suitable for most shells.

‘`shell-escape-always`’  
Like ‘`shell-escape`’, but quote strings even if they would normally not
require quoting.

‘`c`’  
Quote strings as for C character string literals, including the
surrounding double-quote characters; this is the same as the
`--quote-name` (`-Q`) option.

‘`escape`’  
Quote strings as for C character string literals, except omit the
surrounding double-quote characters; this is the same as the `--escape`
(`-b`) option.

‘`clocale`’  
Quote strings as for C character string literals, except use surrounding
quotation marks appropriate for the locale.

‘`locale`’  
Quote strings as for C character string literals, except use surrounding
quotation marks appropriate for the locale, and quote 'like this'
instead of "like this" in the default C locale. This looks nicer on many
displays.

The ‘`r`’, ‘`R`’, ‘`%t`’, and ‘`%T`’ formats operate on the st_rdev
member of the stat(2) structure, i.e., the represented device rather
than the containing device, and so are only defined for character and
block special files. On some systems or file types, st_rdev may be used
to represent other quantities.

The ‘`%W`’, ‘`%X`’, ‘`%Y`’, and ‘`%Z`’ formats accept a precision
preceded by a period to specify the number of digits to print after the
decimal point. For example, ‘`%.3X`’ outputs the access timestamp to
millisecond precision. If a period is given but no precision, `stat`
uses 9 digits, so ‘`%.X`’ is equivalent to ‘`%.9X`’. When discarding
excess precision, timestamps are truncated toward minus infinity.

<div class="example">

``` example
zero pad:
  $ stat -c '[%015Y]' /usr
  [000001288929712]
space align:
  $ stat -c '[%15Y]' /usr
  [     1288929712]
  $ stat -c '[%-15Y]' /usr
  [1288929712     ]
precision:
  $ stat -c '[%.3Y]' /usr
  [1288929712.114]
  $ stat -c '[%.Y]' /usr
  [1288929712.114951834]
```

</div>

The mount point printed by ‘`%m`’ is similar to that output by `df`,
except that:

-   stat does not dereference symlinks by default (unless `-L` is
    specified)
-   stat does not search for specified device nodes in the file system
    list, instead operating on them directly
-   <span id="index-bind-mount-1"></span> stat outputs the alias for a
    bind mounted file, rather than the initial mount point of its
    backing device. One can recursively call stat until there is no
    change in output, to get the current base mount point

When listing file system information (`--file-system` (`-f`)), you must
use a different set of `format` directives:

-   %a - Free blocks available to non-super-user
-   %b - Total data blocks in file system
-   %c - Total file nodes in file system
-   %d - Free file nodes in file system
-   %f - Free blocks in file system
-   %i - File System ID in hex
-   %l - Maximum length of file names
-   %n - File name
-   %s - Block size (for faster transfers)
-   %S - Fundamental block size (for block counts)
-   %t - Type in hex
-   %T - Type in human readable form

<span id="index-TZ-3"></span>

Timestamps are listed according to the time zone rules specified by the
`TZ` environment variable, or by the system default rules if `TZ` is not
set. See [Specifying the Time Zone with
`TZ`](https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#TZ-Variable)
in The GNU C Library Reference Manual.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span
id="sync_003a-Synchronize-cached-writes-to-persistent-storage"></span>

### 14.4 `sync`: Synchronize cached writes to persistent storage

<span id="index-sync-1"></span> <span
id="index-synchronize-file-system-and-memory"></span> <span
id="index-Synchronize-cached-writes-to-persistent-storage"></span>

`sync` synchronizes in memory files or file systems to persistent
storage. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
sync [option] [file]…
```

</div>

<span id="index-superblock_002c-writing"></span> <span
id="index-inodes_002c-written-buffered"></span>

`sync` writes any data buffered in memory out to the storage device.
This can include (but is not limited to) modified superblocks, modified
inodes, and delayed reads and writes. This must be implemented by the
kernel; The `sync` program does nothing but exercise the `sync`,
`syncfs`, `fsync`, and `fdatasync` system calls.

<span id="index-crashes-and-corruption"></span>

The kernel keeps data in memory to avoid doing (relatively slow) device
reads and writes. This improves performance, but if the computer
crashes, data may be lost or the file system corrupted as a result. The
`sync` command instructs the kernel to write data in memory to
persistent storage.

If any argument is specified then only those files will be synchronized
using the fsync(2) syscall by default.

If at least one file is specified, it is possible to change the
synchronization method with the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-d`’  
‘`--data`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002ddata"></span>

Use fdatasync(2) to sync only the data for the file, and any metadata
required to maintain file system consistency.

‘`-f`’  
‘`--file-system`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dfile_002dsystem-1"></span>

Synchronize all the I/O waiting for the file systems that contain the
file, using the syscall syncfs(2). Note you would usually *not* specify
this option if passing a device node like ‘`/dev/sda`’ for example, as
that would sync the containing file system rather than the referenced
one. Note also that depending on the system, passing individual device
nodes or files may have different sync characteristics than using no
arguments. I.e., arguments passed to fsync(2) may provide greater
guarantees through write barriers, than a global sync(2) used when no
arguments are provided.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span id="truncate_003a-Shrink-or-extend-the-size-of-a-file"></span>

### 14.5 `truncate`: Shrink or extend the size of a file

<span id="index-truncate"></span> <span
id="index-truncating_002c-file-sizes"></span>

`truncate` shrinks or extends the size of each `file` to the specified
size. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
truncate option… file…
```

</div>

<span id="index-files_002c-creating"></span>

Any `file` that does not exist is created.

<span id="index-sparse-files_002c-creating"></span> <span
id="index-holes_002c-creating-files-with"></span>

If a `file` is larger than the specified size, the extra data is lost.
If a `file` is shorter, it is extended and the sparse extended part (or
hole) reads as zero bytes.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-c`’  
‘`--no-create`’  
<span id="index-_002dc-21"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dno_002dcreate-1"></span>

Do not create files that do not exist.

‘`-o`’  
‘`--io-blocks`’  
<span id="index-_002do-7"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dio_002dblocks"></span>

Treat `size` as number of I/O blocks of the `file` rather than bytes.

‘`-r rfile`’  
‘`--reference=rfile`’  
<span id="index-_002dr-11"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dreference-4"></span>

Base the size of each `file` on the size of `rfile`.

‘`-s size`’  
‘`--size=size`’  
<span id="index-_002ds-21"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dsize-1"></span>

Set or adjust the size of each `file` according to `size`. `size` is in
bytes unless `--io-blocks` is specified. `size` may be, or may be an
integer optionally followed by, one of the following multiplicative
suffixes:

<div class="example">

``` example
‘KB’ =>           1000 (KiloBytes)
‘K’  =>           1024 (KibiBytes)
‘MB’ =>      1000*1000 (MegaBytes)
‘M’  =>      1024*1024 (MebiBytes)
‘GB’ => 1000*1000*1000 (GigaBytes)
‘G’  => 1024*1024*1024 (GibiBytes)
```

</div>

and so on for ‘`T`’, ‘`P`’, ‘`E`’, ‘`Z`’, and ‘`Y`’. Binary prefixes can
be used, too: ‘`KiB`’=‘`K`’, ‘`MiB`’=‘`M`’, and so on.

`size` may also be prefixed by one of the following to adjust the size
of each `file` based on its current size:

<div class="example">

``` example
‘+’  => extend by
‘-’  => reduce by
‘<’  => at most
‘>’  => at least
‘/’  => round down to multiple of
‘%’  => round up to multiple of
```

</div>

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span id="echo_003a-Print-a-line-of-text"></span>

### 15.1 `echo`: Print a line of text

<span id="index-echo-1"></span> <span id="index-displaying-text"></span>
<span id="index-printing-text"></span> <span
id="index-text_002c-displaying"></span> <span
id="index-arbitrary-text_002c-displaying"></span>

`echo` writes each given `string` to standard output, with a space
between each and a newline after the last one. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
echo [option]… [string]…
```

</div>

<span id="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins-2"></span> <span
id="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with-2"></span>

Due to shell aliases and built-in `echo` functions, using an unadorned
`echo` interactively or in a script may get you different functionality
than that described here. Invoke it via `env` (i.e., `env echo …`) to
avoid interference from the shell.

Due to historical and backwards compatibility reasons, certain bare
option-like strings cannot be passed to `echo` as non-option arguments.
It is therefore not advisable to use `echo` for printing unknown or
variable arguments. The `printf` command is recommended as a more
portable and flexible replacement for tasks historically performed by
`echo`. See [printf invocation](#printf-invocation).

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options). Options must precede operands, and the
normally-special argument ‘`--`’ has no special meaning and is treated
like any other `string`.

‘`-n`’  
<span id="index-_002dn-15"></span>

Do not output the trailing newline.

‘`-e`’  
<span id="index-_002de-5"></span> <span
id="index-backslash-escapes-1"></span>

Enable interpretation of the following backslash-escaped characters in
each `string`:

‘`\a`’  
alert (bell)

‘`\b`’  
backspace

‘`\c`’  
produce no further output

‘`\e`’  
escape

‘`\f`’  
form feed

‘`\n`’  
newline

‘`\r`’  
carriage return

‘`\t`’  
horizontal tab

‘`\v`’  
vertical tab

‘`\\`’  
backslash

‘`\0nnn`’  
the eight-bit value that is the octal number `nnn` (zero to three octal
digits), if `nnn` is a nine-bit value, the ninth bit is ignored

‘`\nnn`’  
the eight-bit value that is the octal number `nnn` (one to three octal
digits), if `nnn` is a nine-bit value, the ninth bit is ignored

‘`\xhh`’  
the eight-bit value that is the hexadecimal number `hh` (one or two
hexadecimal digits)

‘`-E`’  
<span id="index-_002dE-1"></span> <span
id="index-backslash-escapes-2"></span>

Disable interpretation of backslash escapes in each `string`. This is
the default. If `-e` and `-E` are both specified, the last one given
takes effect.

<span id="index-POSIXLY_005fCORRECT-6"></span>

If the `POSIXLY_CORRECT` environment variable is set, then when `echo`’s
first argument is not `-n` it outputs option-like arguments instead of
treating them as options. For example, `echo -ne hello` outputs
‘`-ne hello`’ instead of plain ‘`hello`’. Also backslash escapes are
always enabled. Note to echo the string ‘`-n`’, one of the characters
can be escaped in either octal or hexadecimal representation. For
example, `echo -e '\x2dn'`.

POSIX does not require support for any options, and says that the
behavior of `echo` is implementation-defined if any `string` contains a
backslash or if the first argument is `-n`. Portable programs should use
the `printf` command instead. See [printf
invocation](#printf-invocation).

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span id="printf_003a-Format-and-print-data"></span>

### 15.2 `printf`: Format and print data

<span id="index-printf"></span>

`printf` does formatted printing of text. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
printf format [argument]…
```

</div>

`printf` prints the `format` string, interpreting ‘`%`’ directives and
‘`\`’ escapes to format numeric and string arguments in a way that is
mostly similar to the C ‘`printf`’ function. See [`printf` format
directives](https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#Output-Conversion-Syntax)
in The GNU C Library Reference Manual, for details. The differences are
listed below.

<span id="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins-3"></span> <span
id="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with-3"></span>

Due to shell aliases and built-in `printf` functions, using an unadorned
`printf` interactively or in a script may get you different
functionality than that described here. Invoke it via `env` (i.e.,
`env printf …`) to avoid interference from the shell.

-   The `format` argument is reused as necessary to convert all the
    given `argument`s. For example, the command ‘`printf %s a b`’
    outputs ‘`ab`’.
-   Missing `argument`s are treated as null strings or as zeros,
    depending on whether the context expects a string or a number. For
    example, the command ‘`printf %sx%d`’ prints ‘`x0`’.
-   <span id="index-_005cc"></span> An additional escape, ‘`\c`’, causes
    `printf` to produce no further output. For example, the command
    ‘`printf 'A%sC\cD%sF' B E`’ prints ‘`ABC`’.
-   The hexadecimal escape sequence ‘`\xhh`’ has at most two digits, as
    opposed to C where it can have an unlimited number of digits. For
    example, the command ‘`printf '\x07e'`’ prints two bytes, whereas
    the C statement ‘`printf ("\x07e")`’ prints just one.
-   <span id="index-_0025b"></span> An additional directive ‘`%b`’,
    prints its argument string with ‘`\`’ escapes interpreted in the
    same way as in the `format` string, except that octal escapes are of
    the form ‘`\0ooo`’ where `ooo` is 0 to 3 octal digits. If ‘`\ooo`’
    is nine-bit value, ignore the ninth bit. If a precision is also
    given, it limits the number of bytes printed from the converted
    string.
-   <span id="index-_0025q"></span> An additional directive ‘`%q`’,
    prints its argument string in a format that can be reused as input
    by most shells. Non-printable characters are escaped with the POSIX
    proposed ‘`$''`’ syntax, and shell metacharacters are quoted
    appropriately. This is an equivalent format to
    `ls --quoting=shell-escape` output.
-   Numeric arguments must be single C constants, possibly with leading
    ‘`+`’ or ‘`-`’. For example, ‘`printf %.4d -3`’ outputs ‘`-0003`’.
-   <span id="index-POSIXLY_005fCORRECT-7"></span> If the leading
    character of a numeric argument is ‘`"`’ or ‘`'`’ then its value is
    the numeric value of the immediately following character. Any
    remaining characters are silently ignored if the `POSIXLY_CORRECT`
    environment variable is set; otherwise, a warning is printed. For
    example, ‘`printf "%d" "'a"`’ outputs ‘`97`’ on hosts that use the
    ASCII character set, since ‘`a`’ has the numeric value 97 in ASCII.

<span id="index-LC_005fNUMERIC-5"></span>

A floating point argument is interpreted according to the `LC_NUMERIC`
category of either the current or the C locale, and is printed according
to the current locale. For example, in a locale whose decimal point
character is a comma, the command ‘`printf '%g %g' 2,5 2.5`’ outputs
‘`2,5 2,5`’. See [Floating point](#Floating-point).

<span id="index-_005cooo"></span> <span id="index-_005cxhh"></span>

`printf` interprets ‘`\ooo`’ in `format` as an octal number (if `ooo` is
1 to 3 octal digits) specifying a byte to print, and ‘`\xhh`’ as a
hexadecimal number (if `hh` is 1 to 2 hex digits) specifying a character
to print. Note however that when ‘`\ooo`’ specifies a number larger than
255, `printf` ignores the ninth bit. For example, ‘`printf '\400'`’ is
equivalent to ‘`printf '\0'`’.

<span id="index-_005cuhhhh"></span> <span
id="index-_005cUhhhhhhhh"></span> <span id="index-Unicode"></span> <span
id="index-ISO_002fIEC-10646"></span> <span
id="index-LC_005fCTYPE-4"></span>

`printf` interprets two character syntaxes introduced in ISO C 99:
‘`\u`’ for 16-bit Unicode (ISO/IEC 10646) characters, specified as four
hexadecimal digits `hhhh`, and ‘`\U`’ for 32-bit Unicode characters,
specified as eight hexadecimal digits `hhhhhhhh`. `printf` outputs the
Unicode characters according to the `LC_CTYPE` locale. Unicode
characters in the ranges U+0000…U+009F, U+D800…U+DFFF cannot be
specified by this syntax, except for U+0024 ($), U+0040 (@), and U+0060
()\`.

The processing of ‘`\u`’ and ‘`\U`’ requires a full-featured `iconv`
facility. It is activated on systems with glibc 2.2 (or newer), or when
`libiconv` is installed prior to this package. Otherwise ‘`\u`’ and
‘`\U`’ will print as-is.

The only options are a lone `--help` or `--version`. See [Common
options](#Common-options). Options must precede operands.

The Unicode character syntaxes are useful for writing strings in a
locale independent way. For example, a string containing the Euro
currency symbol

<div class="example">

``` example
$ env printf '\u20AC 14.95'
```

</div>

will be output correctly in all locales supporting the Euro symbol
(ISO-8859-15, UTF-8, and others). Similarly, a Chinese string

<div class="example">

``` example
$ env printf '\u4e2d\u6587'
```

</div>

will be output correctly in all Chinese locales (GB2312, BIG5, UTF-8,
etc).

Note that in these examples, the `printf` command has been invoked via
`env` to ensure that we run the program found via your shell’s search
path, and not a shell alias or a built-in function.

For larger strings, you don’t need to look up the hexadecimal code
values of each character one by one. ASCII characters mixed with \u
escape sequences is also known as the JAVA source file encoding. You can
use GNU recode 3.5c (or newer) to convert strings to this encoding. Here
is how to convert a piece of text into a shell script which will output
this text in a locale-independent way:

<div class="example">

``` example
$ LC_CTYPE=zh_CN.big5 /usr/local/bin/printf \
    '\u4e2d\u6587\n' > sample.txt
$ recode BIG5..JAVA < sample.txt \
    | sed -e "s|^|/usr/local/bin/printf '|" -e "s|$|\\\\n'|" \
    > sample.sh
```

</div>

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span id="yes_003a-Print-a-string-until-interrupted"></span>

### 15.3 `yes`: Print a string until interrupted

<span id="index-yes"></span> <span
id="index-repeated-output-of-a-string"></span>

`yes` prints the command line arguments, separated by spaces and
followed by a newline, forever until it is killed. If no arguments are
given, it prints ‘`y`’ followed by a newline forever until killed.

Upon a write error, `yes` exits with status ‘`1`’.

The only options are a lone `--help` or `--version`. To output an
argument that begins with ‘`-`’, precede it with `--`, e.g.,
‘`yes -- --help`’. See [Common options](#Common-options).

## 16 Conditions

<span id="index-conditions"></span> <span
id="index-commands-for-exit-status"></span> <span
id="index-exit-status-commands"></span>

This section describes commands that are primarily useful for their exit
status, rather than their output. Thus, they are often used as the
condition of shell `if` statements, or as the last command in a
pipeline.

|                                                                  |     |                                      |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|-----|:-------------------------------------|
| • <a href="#false-invocation" accesskey="1">false invocation</a> |     | Do nothing, unsuccessfully.          |
| • <a href="#true-invocation" accesskey="2">true invocation</a>   |     | Do nothing, successfully.            |
| • <a href="#test-invocation" accesskey="3">test invocation</a>   |     | Check file types and compare values. |
| • <a href="#expr-invocation" accesskey="4">expr invocation</a>   |     | Evaluate expressions.                |

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<span id="false-invocation"></span>

<div class="header">

Next:
<a href="#true-invocation" accesskey="n" rel="next">true invocation</a>,
Up: <a href="#Conditions" accesskey="u" rel="up">Conditions</a>  
\[<a href="#SEC_Contents" rel="contents"
title="Table of contents">Contents</a>\]\[<a href="#Concept-index" rel="index" title="Index">Index</a>\]

</div>

<span id="false_003a-Do-nothing_002c-unsuccessfully"></span>

### 16.1 `false`: Do nothing, unsuccessfully

<span id="index-false"></span> <span
id="index-do-nothing_002c-unsuccessfully"></span> <span
id="index-failure-exit-status"></span> <span
id="index-exit-status-of-false"></span>

`false` does nothing except return an exit status of 1, meaning
*failure*. It can be used as a place holder in shell scripts where an
unsuccessful command is needed. In most modern shells, `false` is a
built-in command, so when you use ‘`false`’ in a script, you’re probably
using the built-in command, not the one documented here.

`false` honors the `--help` and `--version` options.

This version of `false` is implemented as a C program, and is thus more
secure and faster than a shell script implementation, and may safely be
used as a dummy shell for the purpose of disabling accounts.

Note that `false` (unlike all other programs documented herein) exits
unsuccessfully, even when invoked with `--help` or `--version`.

Portable programs should not assume that the exit status of `false` is
1, as it is greater than 1 on some non-GNU hosts.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<span id="true_003a-Do-nothing_002c-successfully"></span>

### 16.2 `true`: Do nothing, successfully

<span id="index-true"></span> <span
id="index-do-nothing_002c-successfully"></span> <span
id="index-no_002dop"></span> <span id="index-successful-exit"></span>
<span id="index-exit-status-of-true"></span>

`true` does nothing except return an exit status of 0, meaning
*success*. It can be used as a place holder in shell scripts where a
successful command is needed, although the shell built-in command `:`
(colon) may do the same thing faster. In most modern shells, `true` is a
built-in command, so when you use ‘`true`’ in a script, you’re probably
using the built-in command, not the one documented here.

`true` honors the `--help` and `--version` options.

Note, however, that it is possible to cause `true` to exit with nonzero
status: with the `--help` or `--version` option, and with standard
output already closed or redirected to a file that evokes an I/O error.
For example, using a Bourne-compatible shell:

<div class="example">

``` example
$ ./true --version >&-
./true: write error: Bad file number
$ ./true --version > /dev/full
./true: write error: No space left on device
```

</div>

This version of `true` is implemented as a C program, and is thus more
secure and faster than a shell script implementation, and may safely be
used as a dummy shell for the purpose of disabling accounts.

<span id="test_003a-Check-file-types-and-compare-values"></span>

### 16.3 `test`: Check file types and compare values

<span id="index-test"></span> <span id="index-check-file-types"></span>
<span id="index-compare-values"></span> <span
id="index-expression-evaluation"></span>

`test` returns a status of 0 (true) or 1 (false) depending on the
evaluation of the conditional expression `expr`. Each part of the
expression must be a separate argument.

`test` has file status checks, string operators, and numeric comparison
operators.

`test` has an alternate form that uses opening and closing square
brackets instead a leading ‘`test`’. For example, instead of
‘`test -d /`’, you can write ‘`[ -d / ]`’. The square brackets must be
separate arguments; for example, ‘`[-d /]`’ does not have the desired
effect. Since ‘`test expr`’ and ‘`[ expr ]`’ have the same meaning, only
the former form is discussed below.

Synopses:

<div class="example">

``` example
test expression
test
[ expression ]
[ ]
[ option
```

</div>

<span id="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins-4"></span> <span
id="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with-4"></span>

Due to shell aliases and built-in `test` functions, using an unadorned
`test` interactively or in a script may get you different functionality
than that described here. Invoke it via `env` (i.e., `env test …`) to
avoid interference from the shell.

If `expression` is omitted, `test` returns false. If `expression` is a
single argument, `test` returns false if the argument is null and true
otherwise. The argument can be any string, including strings like
‘`-d`’, ‘`-1`’, ‘`--`’, ‘`--help`’, and ‘`--version`’ that most other
programs would treat as options. To get help and version information,
invoke the commands ‘`[ --help`’ and ‘`[ --version`’, without the usual
closing brackets. See [Common options](#Common-options).

<span id="index-exit-status-of-test"></span>

Exit status:

<div class="display">

``` display
0 if the expression is true,
1 if the expression is false,
2 if an error occurred.
```

</div>

|                                                                          |     |                         |
|:-------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----|:------------------------|

| • <a href="#Access-permission-tests" accesskey="2">Access permission     
 tests</a>                                                                 |     | -\[gkruwxOG\]           |
| • <a href="#File-characteristic-tests" accesskey="3">File characteristic 
 tests</a>                                                                 |     | -e -s -nt -ot -ef       |
| • <a href="#String-tests" accesskey="4">String tests</a>                 |     | -z -n = == !=           |
| • <a href="#Numeric-tests" accesskey="5">Numeric tests</a>               |     | -eq -ne -lt -le -gt -ge |
| • <a href="#Connectives-for-test" accesskey="6">Connectives for test</a> |     | ! -a -o                 |

<span id="File-type-tests-1"></span>

#### 16.3.1 File type tests

<span id="index-file-type-tests"></span>

These options test for particular types of files. (Everything’s a file,
but not all files are the same!)

‘`-b file`’  
<span id="index-_002db-19"></span> <span
id="index-block-special-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and is a block special device.

‘`-c file`’  
<span id="index-_002dc-22"></span> <span
id="index-character-special-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and is a character special device.

‘`-d file`’  
<span id="index-_002dd-16"></span> <span
id="index-directory-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and is a directory.

‘`-f file`’  
<span id="index-_002df-21"></span> <span
id="index-regular-file-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and is a regular file.

‘`-h file`’  
‘`-L file`’  
<span id="index-_002dL-9"></span> <span id="index-_002dh-10"></span>
<span id="index-symbolic-link-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and is a symbolic link. Unlike all other
file-related tests, this test does not dereference `file` if it is a
symbolic link.

‘`-p file`’  
<span id="index-_002dp-7"></span> <span
id="index-named-pipe-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and is a named pipe.

‘`-S file`’  
<span id="index-_002dS-11"></span> <span id="index-socket-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and is a socket.

‘`-t fd`’  
<span id="index-_002dt-18"></span> <span
id="index-terminal-check"></span>

True if `fd` is a file descriptor that is associated with a terminal.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<span id="Access-permission-tests-1"></span>

#### 16.3.2 Access permission tests

<span id="index-access-permission-tests"></span> <span
id="index-permission-tests"></span>

These options test for particular access permissions.

‘`-g file`’  
<span id="index-_002dg-5"></span> <span
id="index-set_002dgroup_002dID-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and has its set-group-ID bit set.

‘`-k file`’  
<span id="index-_002dk-6"></span> <span
id="index-sticky-bit-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and has its *sticky* bit set.

‘`-r file`’  
<span id="index-_002dr-12"></span> <span
id="index-readable-file-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and the user has read access.

‘`-u file`’  
<span id="index-_002du-9"></span> <span
id="index-set_002duser_002dID-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and has its set-user-ID bit set.

‘`-w file`’  
<span id="index-_002dw-11"></span> <span
id="index-writable-file-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and the user has write access.

‘`-x file`’  
<span id="index-_002dx-7"></span> <span
id="index-executable-file-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and the user has execute access (or search
permission, if it is a directory).

‘`-O file`’  
<span id="index-_002dO-1"></span> <span
id="index-owned-by-effective-user-ID-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and is owned by the current effective user ID.

‘`-G file`’  
<span id="index-_002dG-1"></span> <span
id="index-owned-by-effective-group-ID-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and is owned by the current effective group ID.

<span id="File-characteristic-tests-1"></span>

#### 16.3.3 File characteristic tests

<span id="index-file-characteristic-tests"></span>

These options test other file characteristics.

‘`-e file`’  
<span id="index-_002de-6"></span> <span
id="index-existence_002dof_002dfile-check"></span>

True if `file` exists.

‘`-s file`’  
<span id="index-_002ds-22"></span> <span
id="index-nonempty-file-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and has a size greater than zero.

‘`file1 -nt file2`’  
<span id="index-_002dnt"></span> <span
id="index-newer_002dthan-file-check"></span>

True if `file1` is newer (according to modification date) than `file2`,
or if `file1` exists and `file2` does not.

‘`file1 -ot file2`’  
<span id="index-_002dot"></span> <span
id="index-older_002dthan-file-check"></span>

True if `file1` is older (according to modification date) than `file2`,
or if `file2` exists and `file1` does not.

‘`file1 -ef file2`’  
<span id="index-_002def"></span> <span
id="index-same-file-check"></span> <span
id="index-hard-link-check"></span>

True if `file1` and `file2` have the same device and inode numbers,
i.e., if they are hard links to each other.

‘`-N file`’  
<span id="index-_002dN-3"></span> <span
id="index-mtime_002dgreater_002datime-file-check"></span>

True if `file` exists and has been modified (mtime) since it was last
read (atime).

<span id="String-tests-1"></span>

#### 16.3.4 String tests

<span id="index-string-tests"></span>

These options test string characteristics. You may need to quote
`string` arguments for the shell. For example:

<div class="example">

``` example
test -n "$V"
```

</div>

The quotes here prevent the wrong arguments from being passed to `test`
if ‘`$V`’ is empty or contains special characters.

‘`-z string`’  
<span id="index-_002dz-13"></span> <span
id="index-zero_002dlength-string-check"></span>

True if the length of `string` is zero.

‘`-n string`’  
‘`string`’  
<span id="index-_002dn-16"></span> <span
id="index-nonzero_002dlength-string-check"></span>

True if the length of `string` is nonzero.

‘`string1 = string2`’  
<span id="index-_003d-1"></span> <span
id="index-equal-string-check"></span>

True if the strings are equal.

‘`string1 == string2`’  
<span id="index-_003d_003d-1"></span> <span
id="index-equal-string-check-1"></span>

True if the strings are equal (synonym for =). Note this form is not as
portable to other shells and systems.

‘`string1 != string2`’  
<span id="index-_0021_003d"></span> <span
id="index-not_002dequal-string-check"></span>

True if the strings are not equal.

<span id="Numeric-tests-1"></span>

#### 16.3.5 Numeric tests

<span id="index-numeric-tests"></span> <span
id="index-arithmetic-tests"></span>

Numeric relational operators. The arguments must be entirely numeric
(possibly negative), or the special expression `-l string`, which
evaluates to the length of `string`.

‘`arg1 -eq arg2`’  
‘`arg1 -ne arg2`’  
‘`arg1 -lt arg2`’  
‘`arg1 -le arg2`’  
‘`arg1 -gt arg2`’  
‘`arg1 -ge arg2`’  
<span id="index-_002deq"></span> <span id="index-_002dne"></span> <span
id="index-_002dlt"></span> <span id="index-_002dle"></span> <span
id="index-_002dgt"></span> <span id="index-_002dge"></span>

These arithmetic binary operators return true if `arg1` is equal,
not-equal, less-than, less-than-or-equal, greater-than, or
greater-than-or-equal than `arg2`, respectively.

For example:

<div class="example">

``` example
test -1 -gt -2 && echo yes
⇒ yes
test -l abc -gt 1 && echo yes
⇒ yes
test 0x100 -eq 1
error→ test: integer expression expected before -eq
```

</div>

<span id="Connectives-for-test-1"></span>

#### 16.3.6 Connectives for `test`

<span id="index-logical-connectives"></span> <span
id="index-connectives_002c-logical"></span>

Note it’s preferred to use shell logical primitives rather than these
logical connectives internal to `test`, because an expression may become
ambiguous depending on the expansion of its parameters.

For example, this becomes ambiguous when ‘`$1`’ is set to ‘`'!'`’ and
‘`$2`’ to the empty string ‘`''`’:

<div class="example">

``` example
test "$1" -a "$2"
```

</div>

and should be written as:

<div class="example">

``` example
test "$1" && test "$2"
```

</div>

Note the shell logical primitives also benefit from short circuit
operation, which can be significant for file attribute tests.

‘`! expr`’  
<span id="index-_0021"></span>

True if `expr` is false. ‘`!`’ has lower precedence than all parts of
`expr`. Note ‘`!`’ needs to be specified to the left of a binary
expression, I.e., ‘`'!' 1 -gt 2`’ rather than ‘`1 '!' -gt 2`’. Also
‘`!`’ is often a shell special character and is best used quoted.

‘`expr1 -a expr2`’  
<span id="index-_002da-11"></span> <span
id="index-logical-and-operator"></span> <span
id="index-and-operator"></span>

True if both `expr1` and `expr2` are true. ‘`-a`’ is left associative,
and has a higher precedence than ‘`-o`’.

‘`expr1 -o expr2`’  
<span id="index-_002do-8"></span> <span
id="index-logical-or-operator"></span> <span
id="index-or-operator"></span>

True if either `expr1` or `expr2` is true. ‘`-o`’ is left associative.

<span id="expr_003a-Evaluate-expressions"></span>

### 16.4 `expr`: Evaluate expressions

<span id="index-expr"></span> <span
id="index-expression-evaluation-1"></span> <span
id="index-evaluation-of-expressions"></span>

`expr` evaluates an expression and writes the result on standard output.
Each token of the expression must be a separate argument.

Operands are either integers or strings. Integers consist of one or more
decimal digits, with an optional leading ‘`-`’. `expr` converts anything
appearing in an operand position to an integer or a string depending on
the operation being applied to it.

Strings are not quoted for `expr` itself, though you may need to quote
them to protect characters with special meaning to the shell, e.g.,
spaces. However, regardless of whether it is quoted, a string operand
should not be a parenthesis or any of `expr`’s operators like `+`, so
you cannot safely pass an arbitrary string `$str` to expr merely by
quoting it to the shell. One way to work around this is to use the GNU
extension `+`, (e.g., `+ "$str" = foo`); a more portable way is to use
`" $str"` and to adjust the rest of the expression to take the leading
space into account (e.g., `" $str" = " foo"`).

You should not pass a negative integer or a string with leading ‘`-`’ as
`expr`’s first argument, as it might be misinterpreted as an option;
this can be avoided by parenthesization. Also, portable scripts should
not use a string operand that happens to take the form of an integer;
this can be worked around by inserting leading spaces as mentioned
above.

<span id="index-parentheses-for-grouping"></span>

Operators may be given as infix symbols or prefix keywords. Parentheses
may be used for grouping in the usual manner. You must quote parentheses
and many operators to avoid the shell evaluating them, however.

Because `expr` uses multiple-precision arithmetic, it works with
integers wider than those of machine registers.

The only options are `--help` and `--version`. See [Common
options](#Common-options). Options must precede operands.

<span id="index-exit-status-of-expr"></span>

Exit status:

<div class="display">

``` display
0 if the expression is neither null nor 0,
1 if the expression is null or 0,
2 if the expression is invalid,
3 if an internal error occurred (e.g., arithmetic overflow).
```

</div>

|                                                                        |     |                                |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------------|-----|:-------------------------------|
| • <a href="#String-expressions" accesskey="1">String expressions</a>   |     | \+ : match substr index length |
| • <a href="#Numeric-expressions" accesskey="2">Numeric expressions</a> |     | \+ - \* / %                    |
| • <a href="#Relations-for-expr" accesskey="3">Relations for expr</a>   |     | \| & \< \<= = == != \>= \>     |
| • <a href="#Examples-of-expr" accesskey="4">Examples of expr</a>       |     | Examples.                      |

<span id="String-expressions-1"></span>

#### 16.4.1 String expressions

<span id="index-string-expressions"></span> <span
id="index-expressions_002c-string"></span>

`expr` supports pattern matching and other string operators. These have
higher precedence than both the numeric and relational operators (in the
next sections).

‘`string : regex`’  
<span id="index-pattern-matching"></span> <span
id="index-regular-expression-matching"></span> <span
id="index-matching-patterns"></span>

Perform pattern matching. The arguments are converted to strings and the
second is considered to be a (basic, a la GNU `grep`) regular
expression, with a `^` implicitly prepended. The first argument is then
matched against this regular expression.

If `regex` does not use ‘`\(`’ and ‘`\)`’, the `:` expression returns
the number of characters matched, or 0 if the match fails.

If `regex` uses ‘`\(`’ and ‘`\)`’, the `:` expression returns the part
of `string` that matched the subexpression, or the null string if the
match failed or the subexpression did not contribute to the match.

<span id="index-_005c_0028-regexp-operator"></span>

Only the first ‘`\( … \)`’ pair is relevant to the return value;
additional pairs are meaningful only for grouping the regular expression
operators.

<span id="index-_005c_002b-regexp-operator"></span> <span
id="index-_005c_003f-regexp-operator"></span> <span
id="index-_005c_007c-regexp-operator"></span>

In the regular expression, `\+`, `\?`, and `\|` are operators which
respectively match one or more, zero or one, or separate alternatives.
These operators are GNU extensions. See [Regular
Expressions](https://www.gnu.org/software/grep/manual/grep.html#Regular-Expressions)
in The GNU Grep Manual, for details of regular expression syntax. Some
examples are in [Examples of expr](#Examples-of-expr).

‘`match string regex`’  
<span id="index-match"></span>

An alternative way to do pattern matching. This is the same as
‘`string : regex`’.

‘`substr string position length`’  
<span id="index-substr"></span>

Returns the substring of `string` beginning at `position` with length at
most `length`. If either `position` or `length` is negative, zero, or
non-numeric, returns the null string.

‘`index string charset`’  
<span id="index-index"></span>

Returns the first position in `string` where the first character in
`charset` was found. If no character in `charset` is found in `string`,
return 0.

‘`length string`’  
<span id="index-length"></span>

Returns the length of `string`.

‘`+ token`’  
<span id="index-_002b"></span>

Interpret `token` as a string, even if it is a keyword like `match` or
an operator like `/`. This makes it possible to test
`expr length + "$x"` or `expr + "$x" : '.*/\(.\)'` and have it do the
right thing even if the value of `$x` happens to be (for example) `/` or
`index`. This operator is a GNU extension. Portable shell scripts should
use `" $token" : ' \(.*\)'` instead of `+ "$token"`.

To make `expr` interpret keywords as strings, you must use the `quote`
operator.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<span id="Numeric-expressions"></span>

<div class="header">

Next:
<a href="#Relations-for-expr" accesskey="n" rel="next">Relations for
expr</a>, Previous:
<a href="#String-expressions" accesskey="p" rel="prev">String
expressions</a>, Up:
<a href="#expr-invocation" accesskey="u" rel="up">expr invocation</a>  
\[<a href="#SEC_Contents" rel="contents"
title="Table of contents">Contents</a>\]\[<a href="#Concept-index" rel="index" title="Index">Index</a>\]

</div>

<span id="Numeric-expressions-1"></span>

#### 16.4.2 Numeric expressions

<span id="index-numeric-expressions"></span> <span
id="index-expressions_002c-numeric"></span>

`expr` supports the usual numeric operators, in order of increasing
precedence. These numeric operators have lower precedence than the
string operators described in the previous section, and higher
precedence than the connectives (next section).

‘`+ -`’  
<span id="index-_002b-1"></span> <span id="index-_002d"></span> <span
id="index-addition"></span> <span id="index-subtraction"></span>

Addition and subtraction. Both arguments are converted to integers; an
error occurs if this cannot be done.

‘`* / %`’  
<span id="index-_002a"></span> <span id="index-_002f"></span> <span
id="index-_0025"></span> <span id="index-multiplication"></span> <span
id="index-division"></span> <span id="index-remainder"></span>

Multiplication, division, remainder. Both arguments are converted to
integers; an error occurs if this cannot be done.

<div class="header">

expr</a>, Previous:

title="Table of contents">Contents</a>\]\[<a href="#Concept-index" rel="index" title="Index">Index</a>\]

<span id="Relations-for-expr-1"></span>

#### 16.4.3 Relations for `expr`

<span id="index-connectives_002c-logical-1"></span> <span
id="index-logical-connectives-1"></span> <span
id="index-relations_002c-numeric-or-string"></span>

`expr` supports the usual logical connectives and relations. These have
lower precedence than the string and numeric operators (previous
sections). Here is the list, lowest-precedence operator first.

‘`|`’  
<span id="index-_007c"></span> <span
id="index-logical-or-operator-1"></span> <span
id="index-or-operator-1"></span>

Returns its first argument if that is neither null nor zero, otherwise
its second argument if it is neither null nor zero, otherwise 0. It does
not evaluate its second argument if its first argument is neither null
nor zero.

‘`&`’  
<span id="index-_0026"></span> <span
id="index-logical-and-operator-1"></span> <span
id="index-and-operator-1"></span>

Return its first argument if neither argument is null or zero,
otherwise 0. It does not evaluate its second argument if its first
argument is null or zero.

‘`< <= = == != >= >`’  
<span id="index-_003c"></span> <span id="index-_003c_003d"></span> <span
id="index-_003d"></span> <span id="index-_003d_003d"></span> <span
id="index-_003e"></span> <span id="index-_003e_003d"></span> <span
id="index-comparison-operators"></span> <span
id="index-LC_005fCOLLATE-4"></span>

Compare the arguments and return 1 if the relation is true, 0 otherwise.
`==` is a synonym for `=`. `expr` first tries to convert both arguments
to integers and do a numeric comparison; if either conversion fails, it
does a lexicographic comparison using the character collating sequence
specified by the `LC_COLLATE` locale.

<span id="Examples-of-using-expr"></span>

#### 16.4.4 Examples of using `expr`

<span id="index-examples-of-expr"></span>

Here are a few examples, including quoting for shell metacharacters.

To add 1 to the shell variable `foo`, in Bourne-compatible shells:

<div class="example">

``` example
foo=$(expr $foo + 1)
```

</div>

To print the non-directory part of the file name stored in `$fname`,
which need not contain a `/`:

<div class="example">

``` example
expr $fname : '.*/\(.*\)' '|' $fname
```

</div>

An example showing that `\+` is an operator:

<div class="example">

``` example
expr aaa : 'a\+'
⇒ 3
```

</div>

<div class="example">

``` example
expr abc : 'a\(.\)c'
⇒ b
expr index abcdef cz
⇒ 3
expr index index a
error→ expr: syntax error
expr index + index a
⇒ 0
```

</div>

<span id="Redirection-1"></span>

## 17 Redirection

<span id="index-redirection"></span> <span
id="index-commands-for-redirection"></span>

Unix shells commonly provide several forms of *redirection*—ways to
change the input source or output destination of a command. But one
useful redirection is performed by a separate command, not by the shell;
it’s described here.

|                                                              |     |                                                 |
|:-------------------------------------------------------------|-----|:------------------------------------------------|
| • <a href="#tee-invocation" accesskey="1">tee invocation</a> |     | Redirect output to multiple files or processes. |

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<span id="tee-invocation"></span>

<div class="header">

Up: <a href="#Redirection" accesskey="u" rel="up">Redirection</a>  
\[<a href="#SEC_Contents" rel="contents"
title="Table of contents">Contents</a>\]\[<a href="#Concept-index" rel="index" title="Index">Index</a>\]

</div>

<span
id="tee_003a-Redirect-output-to-multiple-files-or-processes"></span>

### 17.1 `tee`: Redirect output to multiple files or processes

<span id="index-tee"></span> <span id="index-pipe-fitting"></span> <span
id="index-destinations_002c-multiple-output"></span> <span
id="index-read-from-standard-input-and-write-to-standard-output-and-files"></span>

The `tee` command copies standard input to standard output and also to
any files given as arguments. This is useful when you want not only to
send some data down a pipe, but also to save a copy. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
tee [option]… [file]…
```

</div>

If a file being written to does not already exist, it is created. If a
file being written to already exists, the data it previously contained
is overwritten unless the `-a` option is used.

In previous versions of GNU Coreutils (v5.3.0 – v8.23), a `file` of
‘`-`’ caused `tee` to send another copy of input to standard output.
However, as the interleaved output was not very useful, `tee` now
conforms to POSIX and treats ‘`-`’ as a file name.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-a`’  
‘`--append`’  
<span id="index-_002da-12"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dappend"></span>

Append standard input to the given files rather than overwriting them.

‘`-i`’  
‘`--ignore-interrupts`’  
<span id="index-_002di-16"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dignore_002dinterrupts"></span>

Ignore interrupt signals.

‘`-p`’  
‘`--output-error[=mode]`’  
<span id="index-_002dp-8"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002doutput_002derror"></span>

Adjust the behavior with errors on the outputs, with the long form
option supporting selection between the following `mode`s:

‘`warn`’  
Warn on error opening or writing any output, including pipes. Writing is
continued to still open files/pipes. Exit status indicates failure if
any output has an error.

‘`warn-nopipe`’  
This is the default `mode` when not specified, or when the short form
`-p` is used. Warn on error opening or writing any output, except pipes.
Writing is continued to still open files/pipes. Exit status indicates
failure if any non pipe output had an error.

‘`exit`’  
Exit on error opening or writing any output, including pipes.

‘`exit-nopipe`’  
Exit on error opening or writing any output, except pipes.

The `tee` command is useful when you happen to be transferring a large
amount of data and also want to summarize that data without reading it a
second time. For example, when you are downloading a DVD image, you
often want to verify its signature or checksum right away. The
inefficient way to do it is simply:

<div class="example">

``` example
wget https://example.com/some.iso && sha1sum some.iso
```

</div>

One problem with the above is that it makes you wait for the download to
complete before starting the time-consuming SHA1 computation. Perhaps
even more importantly, the above requires reading the DVD image a second
time (the first was from the network).

The efficient way to do it is to interleave the download and SHA1
computation. Then, you’ll get the checksum for free, because the entire
process parallelizes so well:

<div class="example">

``` example
# slightly contrived, to demonstrate process substitution
wget -O - https://example.com/dvd.iso \
  | tee >(sha1sum > dvd.sha1) > dvd.iso
```

</div>

That makes `tee` write not just to the expected output file, but also to
a pipe running `sha1sum` and saving the final checksum in a file named
`dvd.sha1`.

Note, however, that this example relies on a feature of modern shells
called *process substitution* (the ‘`>(command)`’ syntax, above; See
[Process
Substitution](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/bash.html#Process-Substitution)
in The Bash Reference Manual.), so it works with `zsh`, `bash`, and
`ksh`, but not with `/bin/sh`. So if you write code like this in a shell
script, be sure to start the script with ‘`#!/bin/bash`’.

Note also that if any of the process substitutions (or piped standard
output) might exit early without consuming all the data, the `-p` option
is needed to allow `tee` to continue to process the input to any
remaining outputs.

Since the above example writes to one file and one process, a more
conventional and portable use of `tee` is even better:

<div class="example">

``` example
wget -O - https://example.com/dvd.iso \
  | tee dvd.iso | sha1sum > dvd.sha1
```

</div>

You can extend this example to make `tee` write to two processes,
computing MD5 and SHA1 checksums in parallel. In this case, process
substitution is required:

<div class="example">

``` example
wget -O - https://example.com/dvd.iso \
  | tee >(sha1sum > dvd.sha1) \
        >(md5sum > dvd.md5) \
  > dvd.iso
```

</div>

This technique is also useful when you want to make a *compressed* copy
of the contents of a pipe. Consider a tool to graphically summarize file
system usage data from ‘`du -ak`’. For a large hierarchy, ‘`du -ak`’ can
run for a long time, and can easily produce terabytes of data, so you
won’t want to rerun the command unnecessarily. Nor will you want to save
the uncompressed output.

Doing it the inefficient way, you can’t even start the GUI until after
you’ve compressed all of the `du` output:

<div class="example">

``` example
du -ak | gzip -9 > /tmp/du.gz
gzip -d /tmp/du.gz | checkspace -a
```

</div>

With `tee` and process substitution, you start the GUI right away and
eliminate the decompression completely:

<div class="example">

``` example
du -ak | tee >(gzip -9 > /tmp/du.gz) | checkspace -a
```

</div>

Finally, if you regularly create more than one type of compressed
tarball at once, for example when `make dist` creates both
`gzip`-compressed and `bzip2`-compressed tarballs, there may be a better
way. Typical `automake`-generated `Makefile` rules create the two
compressed tar archives with commands in sequence, like this (slightly
simplified):

<div class="example">

``` example
tardir=your-pkg-M.N
tar chof - "$tardir" | gzip  -9 -c > your-pkg-M.N.tar.gz
tar chof - "$tardir" | bzip2 -9 -c > your-pkg-M.N.tar.bz2
```

</div>

However, if the hierarchy you are archiving and compressing is larger
than a couple megabytes, and especially if you are using a
multi-processor system with plenty of memory, then you can do much
better by reading the directory contents only once and running the
compression programs in parallel:

<div class="example">

``` example
tardir=your-pkg-M.N
tar chof - "$tardir" \
  | tee >(gzip -9 -c > your-pkg-M.N.tar.gz) \
  | bzip2 -9 -c > your-pkg-M.N.tar.bz2
```

</div>

If you want to further process the output from process substitutions,
and those processes write atomically (i.e., write less than the system’s
PIPE_BUF size at a time), that’s possible with a construct like:

<div class="example">

``` example
tardir=your-pkg-M.N
tar chof - "$tardir" \
  | tee >(md5sum --tag) > >(sha256sum --tag) \
  | sort | gpg --clearsign > your-pkg-M.N.tar.sig
```

</div>

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span
id="basename_003a-Strip-directory-and-suffix-from-a-file-name"></span>

### 18.1 `basename`: Strip directory and suffix from a file name

<span id="index-basename"></span> <span
id="index-strip-directory-and-suffix-from-file-names"></span> <span
id="index-directory_002c-stripping-from-file-names"></span> <span
id="index-suffix_002c-stripping-from-file-names"></span> <span
id="index-file-names_002c-stripping-directory-and-suffix"></span> <span
id="index-leading-directory-components_002c-stripping"></span>

`basename` removes any leading directory components from `name`.
Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
basename name [suffix]
basename option… name…
```

</div>

If `suffix` is specified and is identical to the end of `name`, it is
removed from `name` as well. Note that since trailing slashes are
removed prior to suffix matching, `suffix` will do nothing if it
contains slashes. `basename` prints the result on standard output.

Together, `basename` and `dirname` are designed such that if
‘`ls "$name"`’ succeeds, then the command sequence
‘`cd "$(dirname "$name")"; ls "$(basename "$name")"`’ will, too. This
works for everything except file names containing a trailing newline.

POSIX allows the implementation to define the results if `name` is empty
or ‘`//`’. In the former case, GNU `basename` returns the empty string.
In the latter case, the result is ‘`//`’ on platforms where `//` is
distinct from `/`, and ‘`/`’ on platforms where there is no difference.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options). Options must precede operands.

‘`-a`’  
‘`--multiple`’  
<span id="index-_002da-13"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dmultiple"></span>

Support more than one argument. Treat every argument as a `name`. With
this, an optional `suffix` must be specified using the `-s` option.

‘`-s suffix`’  
‘`--suffix=suffix`’  
<span id="index-_002ds-23"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dsuffix-5"></span>

Remove a trailing `suffix`. This option implies the `-a` option.

‘`-z`’  
‘`--zero`’  
<span id="index-_002dz-14"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dzero-4"></span> <span
id="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines-4"></span>

Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line, rather than a
newline. This option enables other programs to parse the output even
when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

Examples:

<div class="example">

``` example
# Output "sort".
basename /usr/bin/sort

# Output "stdio".
basename include/stdio.h .h

# Output "stdio".
basename -s .h include/stdio.h

# Output "stdio" followed by "stdlib"
basename -a -s .h include/stdio.h include/stdlib.h
```

</div>

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<span id="dirname_003a-Strip-last-file-name-component"></span>

### 18.2 `dirname`: Strip last file name component

<span id="index-dirname"></span> <span
id="index-directory-components_002c-printing"></span> <span
id="index-stripping-non_002ddirectory-suffix"></span> <span
id="index-non_002ddirectory-suffix_002c-stripping"></span>

`dirname` prints all but the final slash-delimited component of each
`name`. Slashes on either side of the final component are also removed.
If the string contains no slash, `dirname` prints ‘`.`’ (meaning the
current directory). Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
dirname [option] name…
```

</div>

`name` need not be a file name, but if it is, this operation effectively
lists the directory that contains the final component, including the
case when the final component is itself a directory.

Together, `basename` and `dirname` are designed such that if
‘`ls "$name"`’ succeeds, then the command sequence
‘`cd "$(dirname "$name")"; ls "$(basename "$name")"`’ will, too. This
works for everything except file names containing a trailing newline.

POSIX allows the implementation to define the results if `name` is
‘`//`’. With GNU `dirname`, the result is ‘`//`’ on platforms where `//`
is distinct from `/`, and ‘`/`’ on platforms where there is no
difference.

The program accepts the following option. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-z`’  
‘`--zero`’  
<span id="index-_002dz-15"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dzero-5"></span> <span
id="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines-5"></span>

Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line, rather than a
newline. This option enables other programs to parse the output even
when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

Examples:

<div class="example">

``` example
# Output "/usr/bin".
dirname /usr/bin/sort
dirname /usr/bin//.//

# Output "dir1" followed by "dir2"
dirname dir1/str dir2/str

# Output ".".
dirname stdio.h
```

</div>

------------------------------------------------------------------------
