<span id="pathchk_003a-Check-file-name-validity-and-portability"></span>

### 18.3 `pathchk`: Check file name validity and portability

<span id="index-pathchk"></span> <span
id="index-file-names_002c-checking-validity-and-portability"></span>
<span id="index-valid-file-names_002c-checking-for"></span> <span
id="index-portable-file-names_002c-checking-for"></span>

`pathchk` checks validity and portability of file names. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
pathchk [option]… name…
```

</div>

For each `name`, `pathchk` prints an error message if any of these
conditions is true:

1.  One of the existing directories in `name` does not have search
    (execute) permission,
2.  The length of `name` is larger than the maximum supported by the
    operating system.
3.  The length of one component of `name` is longer than its file
    system’s maximum.

A nonexistent `name` is not an error, so long as a file with that name
could be created under the above conditions.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options). Options must precede operands.

‘`-p`’  
<span id="index-_002dp-9"></span>

Instead of performing checks based on the underlying file system, print
an error message if any of these conditions is true:

1.  A file name is empty.
2.  A file name contains a character outside the POSIX portable file
    name character set, namely, the ASCII letters and digits, ‘`.`’,
    ‘`_`’, ‘`-`’, and ‘`/`’.
3.  The length of a file name or one of its components exceeds the POSIX
    minimum limits for portability.

‘`-P`’  
<span id="index-_002dP-7"></span>

Print an error message if a file name is empty, or if it contains a
component that begins with ‘`-`’.

‘`--portability`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dportability-1"></span>

Print an error message if a file name is not portable to all POSIX
hosts. This option is equivalent to ‘`-p -P`’.

<span id="index-exit-status-of-pathchk"></span>

Exit status:

<div class="display">

``` display
0 if all specified file names passed all checks,
1 otherwise.
```

</div>

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<div class="header">

invocation</a>, Previous:

<a href="#File-name-manipulation" accesskey="u" rel="up">File name
manipulation</a>   \[<a href="#SEC_Contents" rel="contents"
title="Table of contents">Contents</a>\]\[<a href="#Concept-index" rel="index" title="Index">Index</a>\]

</div>

<span id="mktemp_003a-Create-temporary-file-or-directory"></span>

### 18.4 `mktemp`: Create temporary file or directory

<span id="index-mktemp"></span> <span
id="index-file-names_002c-creating-temporary"></span> <span
id="index-directory_002c-creating-temporary"></span> <span
id="index-temporary-files-and-directories"></span>

`mktemp` manages the creation of temporary files and directories.
Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
mktemp [option]… [template]
```

</div>

Safely create a temporary file or directory based on `template`, and
print its name. If given, `template` must include at least three
consecutive ‘`X`’s in the last component. If omitted, the template
‘`tmp.XXXXXXXXXX`’ is used, and option `--tmpdir` is implied. The final
run of ‘`X`’s in the `template` will be replaced by alpha-numeric
characters; thus, on a case-sensitive file system, and with a `template`
including a run of `n` instances of ‘`X`’, there are ‘`62**n`’ potential
file names.

Older scripts used to create temporary files by simply joining the name
of the program with the process id (‘`$$`’) as a suffix. However, that
naming scheme is easily predictable, and suffers from a race condition
where the attacker can create an appropriately named symbolic link, such
that when the script then opens a handle to what it thought was an
unused file, it is instead modifying an existing file. Using the same
scheme to create a directory is slightly safer, since the `mkdir` will
fail if the target already exists, but it is still inferior because it
allows for denial of service attacks. Therefore, modern scripts should
use the `mktemp` command to guarantee that the generated name will be
unpredictable, and that knowledge of the temporary file name implies
that the file was created by the current script and cannot be modified
by other users.

When creating a file, the resulting file has read and write permissions
for the current user, but no permissions for the group or others; these
permissions are reduced if the current umask is more restrictive.

Here are some examples (although note that if you repeat them, you will
most likely get different file names):

-   Create a temporary file in the current directory.
    <div class="example">

    ``` example
    $ mktemp file.XXXX
    file.H47c
    ```

    </div>
-   Create a temporary file with a known suffix.
    <div class="example">

    ``` example
    $ mktemp --suffix=.txt file-XXXX
    file-H08W.txt
    $ mktemp file-XXXX-XXXX.txt
    file-XXXX-eI9L.txt
    ```

    </div>
-   Create a secure fifo relative to the user’s choice of `TMPDIR`, but
    falling back to the current directory rather than `/tmp`. Note that
    `mktemp` does not create fifos, but can create a secure directory in
    which the fifo can live. Exit the shell if the directory or fifo
    could not be created.
    <div class="example">

    ``` example
    $ dir=$(mktemp -p "${TMPDIR:-.}" -d dir-XXXX) || exit 1
    $ fifo=$dir/fifo
    $ mkfifo "$fifo" || { rmdir "$dir"; exit 1; }
    ```

    </div>
-   Create and use a temporary file if possible, but ignore failure. The
    file will reside in the directory named by `TMPDIR`, if specified,
    or else in `/tmp`.
    <div class="example">

    ``` example
    $ file=$(mktemp -q) && {
    >   # Safe to use $file only within this block.  Use quotes,
    >   # since $TMPDIR, and thus $file, may contain whitespace.
    >   echo ... > "$file"
    >   rm "$file"
    > }
    ```

    </div>
-   Act as a semi-random character generator (it is not fully random,
    since it is impacted by the contents of the current directory). To
    avoid security holes, do not use the resulting names to create a
    file.
    <div class="example">

    ``` example
    $ mktemp -u XXX
    Gb9
    $ mktemp -u XXX
    nzC
    ```

    </div>

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-d`’  
‘`--directory`’  
<span id="index-_002dd-17"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002ddirectory-3"></span>

Create a directory rather than a file. The directory will have read,
write, and search permissions for the current user, but no permissions
for the group or others; these permissions are reduced if the current
umask is more restrictive.

‘`-q`’  
‘`--quiet`’  
<span id="index-_002dq-5"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dquiet-8"></span>

Suppress diagnostics about failure to create a file or directory. The
exit status will still reflect whether a file was created.

‘`-u`’  
‘`--dry-run`’  
<span id="index-_002du-10"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002ddry_002drun"></span>

Generate a temporary name that does not name an existing file, without
changing the file system contents. Using the output of this command to
create a new file is inherently unsafe, as there is a window of time
between generating the name and using it where another process can
create an object by the same name.

‘`-p dir`’  
‘`--tmpdir[=dir]`’  
<span id="index-_002dp-10"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dtmpdir"></span>

Treat `template` relative to the directory `dir`. If `dir` is not
specified (only possible with the long option `--tmpdir`) or is the
empty string, use the value of `TMPDIR` if available, otherwise use
‘`/tmp`’. If this is specified, `template` must not be absolute.
However, `template` can still contain slashes, although intermediate
directories must already exist.

‘`--suffix=suffix`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dsuffix-6"></span>

Append `suffix` to the `template`. `suffix` must not contain slash. If
`--suffix` is specified, `template` must end in ‘`X`’; if it is not
specified, then an appropriate `--suffix` is inferred by finding the
last ‘`X`’ in `template`. This option exists for use with the default
`template` and for the creation of a `suffix` that starts with ‘`X`’.

‘`-t`’  
<span id="index-_002dt-19"></span>

Treat `template` as a single file relative to the value of `TMPDIR` if
available, or to the directory specified by `-p`, otherwise to ‘`/tmp`’.
`template` must not contain slashes. This option is deprecated; the use
of `-p` without `-t` offers better defaults (by favoring the command
line over `TMPDIR`) and more flexibility (by allowing intermediate
directories).

<span id="index-exit-status-of-mktemp"></span>

Exit status:

<div class="display">

``` display
0 if the file was created,
1 otherwise.
```

</div>

<span id="realpath_003a-Print-the-resolved-file-name_002e"></span>

### 18.5 `realpath`: Print the resolved file name.

<span id="index-realpath-2"></span> <span
id="index-file-names_002c-canonicalization"></span> <span
id="index-symlinks_002c-resolution"></span> <span
id="index-canonical-file-name-1"></span> <span
id="index-canonicalize-a-file-name-1"></span> <span
id="index-realpath-3"></span> <span id="index-realpath-1"></span>

`realpath` expands all symbolic links and resolves references to
‘`/./`’, ‘`/../`’ and extra ‘`/`’ characters. By default, all but the
last component of the specified files must exist. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
realpath [option]… file…
```

</div>

The file name canonicalization functionality overlaps with that of the
`readlink` command. This is the preferred command for canonicalization
as it’s a more suitable and standard name. In addition this command
supports relative file name processing functionality.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-e`’  
‘`--canonicalize-existing`’  
<span id="index-_002de-7"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dcanonicalize_002dexisting-1"></span>

Ensure that all components of the specified file names exist. If any
component is missing or unavailable, `realpath` will output a diagnostic
unless the `-q` option is specified, and exit with a nonzero exit code.
A trailing slash requires that the name resolve to a directory.

‘`-m`’  
‘`--canonicalize-missing`’  
<span id="index-_002dm-11"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dcanonicalize_002dmissing-1"></span>

If any component of a specified file name is missing or unavailable,
treat it as a directory.

‘`-L`’  
‘`--logical`’  
<span id="index-_002dL-10"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dlogical-1"></span>

Symbolic links are resolved in the specified file names, but they are
resolved after any subsequent ‘`..`’ components are processed.

‘`-P`’  
‘`--physical`’  
<span id="index-_002dP-8"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dphysical-1"></span>

Symbolic links are resolved in the specified file names, and they are
resolved before any subsequent ‘`..`’ components are processed. This is
the default mode of operation.

‘`-q`’  
‘`--quiet`’  
<span id="index-_002dq-6"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dquiet-9"></span>

Suppress diagnostic messages for specified file names.

‘`--relative-to=dir`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002drelative_002dto"></span> <span
id="index-relpath"></span>

Print the resolved file names relative to the specified directory. Note
this option honors the `-m` and `-e` options pertaining to file
existence.

‘`--relative-base=dir`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002drelative_002dbase"></span>

Print the resolved file names as relative *if* the files are descendants
of `dir`. Otherwise, print the resolved file names as absolute. Note
this option honors the `-m` and `-e` options pertaining to file
existence. For details about combining `--relative-to` and
`--relative-base`, see [Realpath usage
examples](#Realpath-usage-examples).

‘`-s`’  
‘`--strip`’  
‘`--no-symlinks`’  
<span id="index-_002ds-24"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dstrip-1"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dno_002dsymlinks"></span>

Do not resolve symbolic links. Only resolve references to ‘`/./`’,
‘`/../`’ and remove extra ‘`/`’ characters. When combined with the `-m`
option, realpath operates only on the file name, and does not touch any
actual file.

‘`-z`’  
‘`--zero`’  
<span id="index-_002dz-16"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dzero-6"></span> <span
id="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines-6"></span>

Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line, rather than a
newline. This option enables other programs to parse the output even
when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.

<span id="index-exit-status-of-realpath"></span>

Exit status:

<div class="display">

``` display
0 if all file names were printed without issue.
1 otherwise.
```

</div>

 examples</a>                                                       |     | Realpath usage examples. |

<span id="Realpath-usage-examples-1"></span>

#### 18.5.1 Realpath usage examples

<span id="index-_002d_002drelative_002dto-1"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002drelative_002dbase-1"></span>

By default, `realpath` prints the absolute file name of given files
(symlinks are resolved, `words` is resolved to `american-english`):

<div class="example">

``` example
cd /home/user
realpath /usr/bin/sort /tmp/foo /usr/share/dict/words 1.txt
⇒ /usr/bin/sort
⇒ /tmp/foo
⇒ /usr/share/dict/american-english
⇒ /home/user/1.txt
```

</div>

With `--relative-to`, file names are printed relative to the given
directory:

<div class="example">

``` example
realpath --relative-to=/usr/bin \
         /usr/bin/sort /tmp/foo /usr/share/dict/words 1.txt
⇒ sort
⇒ ../../tmp/foo
⇒ ../share/dict/american-english
⇒ ../../home/user/1.txt
```

</div>

With `--relative-base`, relative file names are printed *if* the
resolved file name is below the given base directory. For files outside
the base directory absolute file names are printed:

<div class="example">

``` example
realpath --relative-base=/usr \
         /usr/bin/sort /tmp/foo /usr/share/dict/words 1.txt
⇒ bin/sort
⇒ /tmp/foo
⇒ share/dict/american-english
⇒ /home/user/1.txt
```

</div>

When both `--relative-to=DIR1` and `--relative-base=DIR2` are used, file
names are printed relative to `dir1` *if* they are located below `dir2`.
If the files are not below `dir2`, they are printed as absolute file
names:

<div class="example">

``` example
realpath --relative-to=/usr/bin --relative-base=/usr \
         /usr/bin/sort /tmp/foo /usr/share/dict/words 1.txt
⇒ sort
⇒ /tmp/foo
⇒ ../share/dict/american-english
⇒ /home/user/1.txt
```

</div>

When both `--relative-to=DIR1` and `--relative-base=DIR2` are used,
`dir1` *must* be a subdirectory of `dir2`. Otherwise, `realpath` prints
absolutes file names.

## 19 Working context

<span id="index-working-context"></span> <span
id="index-commands-for-printing-the-working-context"></span>

which you are working: the current directory, the terminal settings, and
so forth. See also the user-related commands in the next section.

| • <a href="#printenv-invocation" accesskey="3">printenv invocation</a> |     | Print environment variables.                   |
| • <a href="#tty-invocation" accesskey="4">tty invocation</a>           |     | Print file name of terminal on standard input. |

<span id="pwd_003a-Print-working-directory"></span>

### 19.1 `pwd`: Print working directory

<span id="index-pwd"></span> <span
id="index-print-name-of-current-directory"></span> <span
id="index-current-working-directory_002c-printing"></span> <span
id="index-working-directory_002c-printing"></span>

`pwd` prints the name of the current directory. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
pwd [option]…
```

</div>

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-L`’  
‘`--logical`’  
<span id="index-_002dL-11"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dlogical-2"></span>

If the contents of the environment variable `PWD` provide an absolute
name of the current directory with no ‘`.`’ or ‘`..`’ components, but
possibly with symbolic links, then output those contents. Otherwise,
fall back to default `-P` handling.

‘`-P`’  
‘`--physical`’  
<span id="index-_002dP-9"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dphysical-2"></span>

Print a fully resolved name for the current directory. That is, all
components of the printed name will be actual directory names—none will
be symbolic links.

<span id="index-symbolic-links-and-pwd"></span>

If `-L` and `-P` are both given, the last one takes precedence. If
neither option is given, then this implementation uses `-P` as the
default unless the `POSIXLY_CORRECT` environment variable is set.

<span id="index-conflicts-with-shell-built_002dins-5"></span> <span
id="index-built_002din-shell-commands_002c-conflicts-with-5"></span>

Due to shell aliases and built-in `pwd` functions, using an unadorned
`pwd` interactively or in a script may get you different functionality
than that described here. Invoke it via `env` (i.e., `env pwd …`) to
avoid interference from the shell.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span id="stty_003a-Print-or-change-terminal-characteristics"></span>

### 19.2 `stty`: Print or change terminal characteristics

<span id="index-stty"></span> <span
id="index-change-or-print-terminal-settings"></span> <span
id="index-terminal-settings"></span> <span
id="index-line-settings-of-terminal"></span>

`stty` prints or changes terminal characteristics, such as baud rate.
Synopses:

<div class="example">

``` example
stty [option] [setting]…
stty [option]
```

</div>

If given no line settings, `stty` prints the baud rate, line discipline
number (on systems that support it), and line settings that have been
changed from the values set by ‘`stty sane`’. By default, mode reading
and setting are performed on the tty line connected to standard input,
although this can be modified by the `--file` option.

`stty` accepts many non-option arguments that change aspects of the
terminal line operation, as described below.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-a`’  
‘`--all`’  
<span id="index-_002da-14"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dall-4"></span>

Print all current settings in human-readable form. This option may not
be used in combination with any line settings.

‘`-F device`’  
‘`--file=device`’  
<span id="index-_002dF-5"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dfile"></span>

Set the line opened by the file name specified in `device` instead of
the tty line connected to standard input. This option is necessary
because opening a POSIX tty requires use of the `O_NONDELAY` flag to
prevent a POSIX tty from blocking until the carrier detect line is high
if the `clocal` flag is not set. Hence, it is not always possible to
allow the shell to open the device in the traditional manner.

‘`-g`’  
‘`--save`’  
<span id="index-_002dg-6"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dsave"></span> <span
id="index-machine_002dreadable-stty-output"></span>

Print all current settings in a form that can be used as an argument to
another `stty` command to restore the current settings. This option may
not be used in combination with any line settings.

Many settings can be turned off by preceding them with a ‘`-`’. Such
arguments are marked below with “May be negated” in their description.
The descriptions themselves refer to the positive case, that is, when
*not* negated (unless stated otherwise, of course).

Some settings are not available on all POSIX systems, since they use
extensions. Such arguments are marked below with “Non-POSIX” in their
description. On non-POSIX systems, those or other settings also may not
be available, but it’s not feasible to document all the variations: just
try it and see.

`stty` is installed only on platforms with the POSIX terminal interface,
so portable scripts should not rely on its existence on non-POSIX
platforms.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span id="Control-settings"></span>

#### 19.2.1 Control settings

<span id="index-control-settings"></span>

Control settings:

‘`parenb`’  
<span id="index-parenb"></span> <span
id="index-two_002dway-parity"></span>

Generate parity bit in output and expect parity bit in input. May be
negated.

‘`parodd`’  
<span id="index-parodd"></span> <span id="index-odd-parity"></span>
<span id="index-even-parity"></span>

Set odd parity (even if negated). May be negated.

‘`cmspar`’  
<span id="index-cmspar"></span> <span id="index-constant-parity"></span>
<span id="index-stick-parity"></span> <span
id="index-mark-parity"></span> <span id="index-space-parity"></span>

Use "stick" (mark/space) parity. If parodd is set, the parity bit is
always 1; if parodd is not set, the parity bit is always zero.
Non-POSIX. May be negated.

‘`cs5`’  
‘`cs6`’  
‘`cs7`’  
‘`cs8`’  
<span id="index-csn"></span> <span id="index-character-size"></span>
<span id="index-eight_002dbit-characters"></span>

Set character size to 5, 6, 7, or 8 bits.

‘`hup`’  
‘`hupcl`’  
<span id="index-hup_005bcl_005d"></span>

Send a hangup signal when the last process closes the tty. May be
negated.

‘`cstopb`’  
<span id="index-cstopb"></span> <span id="index-stop-bits"></span>

Use two stop bits per character (one if negated). May be negated.

‘`cread`’  
<span id="index-cread"></span>

Allow input to be received. May be negated.

‘`clocal`’  
<span id="index-clocal"></span> <span id="index-modem-control"></span>

Disable modem control signals. May be negated.

‘`crtscts`’  
<span id="index-crtscts"></span> <span
id="index-hardware-flow-control"></span> <span
id="index-flow-control_002c-hardware"></span> <span
id="index-RTS_002fCTS-flow-control"></span>

Enable RTS/CTS flow control. Non-POSIX. May be negated.

‘`cdtrdsr`’  
<span id="index-cdtrdsr"></span> <span
id="index-hardware-flow-control-1"></span> <span
id="index-flow-control_002c-hardware-1"></span> <span
id="index-DTR_002fDSR-flow-control"></span>

Enable DTR/DSR flow control. Non-POSIX. May be negated.

<span id="Input-settings"></span>

#### 19.2.2 Input settings

<span id="index-input-settings"></span>

These settings control operations on data received from the terminal.

‘`ignbrk`’  
<span id="index-ignbrk"></span> <span
id="index-breaks_002c-ignoring"></span>

Ignore break characters. May be negated.

‘`brkint`’  
<span id="index-brkint"></span> <span
id="index-breaks_002c-cause-interrupts"></span>

Make breaks cause an interrupt signal. May be negated.

‘`ignpar`’  
<span id="index-ignpar"></span> <span
id="index-parity_002c-ignoring"></span>

Ignore characters with parity errors. May be negated.

‘`parmrk`’  
<span id="index-parmrk"></span> <span
id="index-parity-errors_002c-marking"></span>

Mark parity errors (with a 255-0-character sequence). May be negated.

‘`inpck`’  
<span id="index-inpck"></span>

Enable input parity checking. May be negated.

‘`istrip`’  
<span id="index-istrip"></span> <span
id="index-eight_002dbit-input"></span>

Clear high (8th) bit of input characters. May be negated.

‘`inlcr`’  
<span id="index-inlcr"></span> <span
id="index-newline_002c-translating-to-return"></span>

Translate newline to carriage return. May be negated.

‘`igncr`’  
<span id="index-igncr"></span> <span
id="index-return_002c-ignoring"></span>

Ignore carriage return. May be negated.

‘`icrnl`’  
<span id="index-icrnl"></span> <span
id="index-return_002c-translating-to-newline"></span>

Translate carriage return to newline. May be negated.

‘`iutf8`’  
<span id="index-iutf8"></span> <span
id="index-input-encoding_002c-UTF_002d8"></span>

Assume input characters are UTF-8 encoded. May be negated.

‘`ixon`’  
<span id="index-ixon"></span> <span
id="index-C_002ds_002fC_002dq-flow-control"></span> <span
id="index-XON_002fXOFF-flow-control"></span>

Enable XON/XOFF flow control (that is, <span
class="kbd">Ctrl-S</span>/<span class="kbd">Ctrl-Q</span>). May be
negated.

‘`ixoff`’  
‘`tandem`’  
<span id="index-ixoff"></span> <span id="index-tandem"></span> <span
id="index-software-flow-control"></span> <span
id="index-flow-control_002c-software"></span>

Enable sending of `stop` character when the system input buffer is
almost full, and `start` character when it becomes almost empty again.
May be negated.

‘`iuclc`’  
<span id="index-iuclc"></span> <span
id="index-uppercase_002c-translating-to-lowercase"></span>

Translate uppercase characters to lowercase. Non-POSIX. May be negated.
Note ilcuc is not implemented, as one would not be able to issue almost
any (lowercase) Unix command, after invoking it.

‘`ixany`’  
<span id="index-ixany"></span>

Allow any character to restart output (only the start character if
negated). Non-POSIX. May be negated.

‘`imaxbel`’  
<span id="index-imaxbel"></span> <span
id="index-beeping-at-input-buffer-full"></span>

Enable beeping and not flushing input buffer if a character arrives when
the input buffer is full. Non-POSIX. May be negated.

<span id="Output-settings"></span>

#### 19.2.3 Output settings

<span id="index-output-settings"></span>

These settings control operations on data sent to the terminal.

‘`opost`’  
<span id="index-opost"></span>

Postprocess output. May be negated.

‘`olcuc`’  
<span id="index-olcuc"></span> <span
id="index-lowercase_002c-translating-to-output"></span>

Translate lowercase characters to uppercase. Non-POSIX. May be negated.
(Note ouclc is not currently implemented.)

‘`ocrnl`’  
<span id="index-ocrnl"></span> <span
id="index-return_002c-translating-to-newline-1"></span>

Translate carriage return to newline. Non-POSIX. May be negated.

‘`onlcr`’  
<span id="index-onlcr"></span> <span
id="index-newline_002c-translating-to-crlf"></span>

Translate newline to carriage return-newline. Non-POSIX. May be negated.

‘`onocr`’  
<span id="index-onocr"></span>

Do not print carriage returns in the first column. Non-POSIX. May be
negated.

‘`onlret`’  
<span id="index-onlret"></span>

Newline performs a carriage return. Non-POSIX. May be negated.

‘`ofill`’  
<span id="index-ofill"></span> <span
id="index-pad-instead-of-timing-for-delaying"></span>

Use fill (padding) characters instead of timing for delays. Non-POSIX.
May be negated.

‘`ofdel`’  
<span id="index-ofdel"></span> <span id="index-pad-character"></span>

Use ASCII DEL characters for fill instead of ASCII NUL characters.
Non-POSIX. May be negated.

‘`nl1`’  
‘`nl0`’  
<span id="index-nln"></span>

Newline delay style. Non-POSIX.

‘`cr3`’  
‘`cr2`’  
‘`cr1`’  
‘`cr0`’  
<span id="index-crn"></span>

Carriage return delay style. Non-POSIX.

‘`tab3`’  
‘`tab2`’  
‘`tab1`’  
‘`tab0`’  
<span id="index-tabn"></span>

Horizontal tab delay style. Non-POSIX.

‘`bs1`’  
‘`bs0`’  
<span id="index-bsn"></span>

Backspace delay style. Non-POSIX.

‘`vt1`’  
‘`vt0`’  
<span id="index-vtn"></span>

Vertical tab delay style. Non-POSIX.

‘`ff1`’  
‘`ff0`’  
<span id="index-ffn"></span>

Form feed delay style. Non-POSIX.

<span id="Local-settings"></span>

#### 19.2.4 Local settings

<span id="index-local-settings"></span>

‘`isig`’  
<span id="index-isig"></span>

Enable `interrupt`, `quit`, and `suspend` special characters. May be
negated.

‘`icanon`’  
<span id="index-icanon"></span>

Enable `erase`, `kill`, `werase`, and `rprnt` special characters. May be
negated.

‘`iexten`’  
<span id="index-iexten"></span>

Enable non-POSIX special characters. May be negated.

‘`echo`’  
<span id="index-echo"></span>

Echo input characters. May be negated.

‘`echoe`’  
‘`crterase`’  
<span id="index-echoe"></span> <span id="index-crterase"></span>

Echo `erase` characters as backspace-space-backspace. May be negated.

‘`echok`’  
<span id="index-echok"></span> <span
id="index-newline-echoing-after-kill"></span>

Echo a newline after a `kill` character. May be negated.

‘`echonl`’  
<span id="index-echonl"></span> <span
id="index-newline_002c-echoing"></span>

Echo newline even if not echoing other characters. May be negated.

‘`noflsh`’  
<span id="index-noflsh"></span> <span
id="index-flushing_002c-disabling"></span>

Disable flushing after `interrupt` and `quit` special characters. May be
negated.

‘`xcase`’  
<span id="index-xcase"></span> <span id="index-case-translation"></span>

Enable input and output of uppercase characters by preceding their
lowercase equivalents with ‘`\`’, when `icanon` is set. Non-POSIX. May
be negated.

‘`tostop`’  
<span id="index-tostop"></span> <span
id="index-background-jobs_002c-stopping-at-terminal-write"></span>

Stop background jobs that try to write to the terminal. Non-POSIX. May
be negated.

‘`echoprt`’  
‘`prterase`’  
<span id="index-echoprt"></span> <span id="index-prterase"></span>

Echo erased characters backward, between ‘`\`’ and ‘`/`’. Non-POSIX. May
be negated.

‘`echoctl`’  
‘`ctlecho`’  
<span id="index-echoctl"></span> <span id="index-ctlecho"></span> <span
id="index-control-characters_002c-using-_005ec"></span> <span
id="index-hat-notation-for-control-characters"></span>

Echo control characters in hat notation (‘`^c`’) instead of literally.
Non-POSIX. May be negated.

‘`echoke`’  
‘`crtkill`’  
<span id="index-echoke"></span> <span id="index-crtkill"></span>

Echo the `kill` special character by erasing each character on the line
as indicated by the `echoprt` and `echoe` settings, instead of by the
`echoctl` and `echok` settings. Non-POSIX. May be negated.

‘`extproc`’  
<span id="index-extproc"></span>

Enable ‘`LINEMODE`’, which is used to avoid echoing each character over
high latency links. See also [Internet RFC
1116](https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc1116). Non-POSIX. May be negated.

‘`flusho`’  
<span id="index-flusho"></span>

Discard output. Note this setting is currently ignored on GNU/Linux
systems. Non-POSIX. May be negated.

<span id="Combination-settings"></span>

#### 19.2.5 Combination settings

<span id="index-combination-settings"></span>

Combination settings:

‘`evenp`’  
<span id="index-evenp"></span>

‘`parity`’  
<span id="index-parity"></span>

Same as `parenb -parodd cs7`. May be negated. If negated, same as
`-parenb cs8`.

‘`oddp`’  
<span id="index-oddp"></span>

Same as `parenb parodd cs7`. May be negated. If negated, same as
`-parenb cs8`.

‘`nl`’  
<span id="index-nl"></span>

Same as `-icrnl -onlcr`. May be negated. If negated, same as
`icrnl -inlcr -igncr onlcr -ocrnl -onlret`.

‘`ek`’  
<span id="index-ek"></span>

Reset the `erase` and `kill` special characters to their default values.

‘`sane`’  
<span id="index-sane"></span>

Same as:

<div class="example">

``` example
cread -ignbrk brkint -inlcr -igncr icrnl
icanon iexten echo echoe echok -echonl -noflsh
-ixoff -iutf8 -iuclc -ixany imaxbel -xcase -olcuc -ocrnl
opost -ofill onlcr -onocr -onlret nl0 cr0 tab0 bs0 vt0 ff0
isig -tostop -ofdel -echoprt echoctl echoke -extproc
```

</div>

and also sets all special characters to their default values.

‘`cooked`’  
<span id="index-cooked"></span>

Same as `brkint ignpar istrip icrnl ixon opost isig icanon`, plus sets
the `eof` and `eol` characters to their default values if they are the
same as the `min` and `time` characters. May be negated. If negated,
same as `raw`.

‘`raw`’  
<span id="index-raw"></span>

Same as:

<div class="example">

``` example
-ignbrk -brkint -ignpar -parmrk -inpck -istrip
-inlcr -igncr -icrnl -ixon -ixoff -icanon -opost
-isig -iuclc -ixany -imaxbel -xcase min 1 time 0
```

</div>

May be negated. If negated, same as `cooked`.

‘`cbreak`’  
<span id="index-cbreak"></span>

Same as `-icanon`. May be negated. If negated, same as `icanon`.

‘`pass8`’  
<span id="index-pass8"></span> <span
id="index-eight_002dbit-characters-1"></span>

Same as `-parenb -istrip cs8`. May be negated. If negated, same as
`parenb istrip cs7`.

‘`litout`’  
<span id="index-litout"></span>

Same as `-parenb -istrip -opost cs8`. May be negated. If negated, same
as `parenb istrip opost cs7`.

‘`decctlq`’  
<span id="index-decctlq"></span>

Same as `-ixany`. Non-POSIX. May be negated.

‘`tabs`’  
<span id="index-tabs"></span>

Same as `tab0`. Non-POSIX. May be negated. If negated, same as `tab3`.

‘`lcase`’  
‘`LCASE`’  
<span id="index-lcase"></span> <span id="index-LCASE"></span>

Same as `xcase iuclc olcuc`. Non-POSIX. May be negated. (Used for
terminals with uppercase characters only.)

‘`crt`’  
<span id="index-crt"></span>

Same as `echoe echoctl echoke`.

‘`dec`’  
<span id="index-dec"></span>

Same as `echoe echoctl echoke -ixany intr ^C erase ^? kill C-u`.

<span id="Special-characters"></span>

#### 19.2.6 Special characters

<span id="index-special-characters"></span> <span
id="index-characters_002c-special"></span>

The special characters’ default values vary from system to system. They
are set with the syntax ‘`name value`’, where the names are listed below
and the value can be given either literally, in hat notation (‘`^c`’),
or as an integer which may start with ‘`0x`’ to indicate hexadecimal,
‘`0`’ to indicate octal, or any other digit to indicate decimal.

<span id="index-disabling-special-characters"></span> <span
id="index-u_002c-and-disabling-special-characters"></span>

For GNU stty, giving a value of `^-` or `undef` disables that special
character. (This is incompatible with Ultrix `stty`, which uses a value
of ‘`u`’ to disable a special character. GNU `stty` treats a value ‘`u`’
like any other, namely to set that special character to U.)

‘`intr`’  
<span id="index-intr"></span>

Send an interrupt signal.

‘`quit`’  
<span id="index-quit"></span>

Send a quit signal.

‘`erase`’  
<span id="index-erase"></span>

Erase the last character typed.

‘`kill`’  
<span id="index-kill"></span>

Erase the current line.

‘`eof`’  
<span id="index-eof"></span>

Send an end of file (terminate the input).

‘`eol`’  
<span id="index-eol"></span>

End the line.

‘`eol2`’  
<span id="index-eol2"></span>

Alternate character to end the line. Non-POSIX.

‘`discard`’  
<span id="index-discard"></span> <span id="index-flush"></span>

Alternate character to toggle discarding of output. Non-POSIX.

‘`swtch`’  
<span id="index-swtch"></span>

Switch to a different shell layer. Non-POSIX.

‘`status`’  
<span id="index-status-1"></span>

Send an info signal. Not currently supported on GNU/Linux. Non-POSIX.

‘`start`’  
<span id="index-start"></span>

Restart the output after stopping it.

‘`stop`’  
<span id="index-stop"></span>

Stop the output.

‘`susp`’  
<span id="index-susp"></span>

Send a terminal stop signal.

‘`dsusp`’  
<span id="index-dsusp"></span>

Send a terminal stop signal after flushing the input. Non-POSIX.

‘`rprnt`’  
<span id="index-rprnt"></span>

Redraw the current line. Non-POSIX.

‘`werase`’  
<span id="index-werase"></span>

Erase the last word typed. Non-POSIX.

‘`lnext`’  
<span id="index-lnext"></span>

Enter the next character typed literally, even if it is a special
character. Non-POSIX.

<span id="Special-settings"></span>

#### 19.2.7 Special settings

<span id="index-special-settings"></span>

‘`min n`’  
<span id="index-min"></span>

Set the minimum number of characters that will satisfy a read until the
time value has expired, when `-icanon` is set.

‘`time n`’  
<span id="index-time-1"></span>

Set the number of tenths of a second before reads time out if the
minimum number of characters have not been read, when `-icanon` is set.

‘`ispeed n`’  
<span id="index-ispeed"></span>

Set the input speed to `n`.

‘`ospeed n`’  
<span id="index-ospeed"></span>

Set the output speed to `n`.

‘`rows n`’  
<span id="index-rows"></span>

Tell the tty kernel driver that the terminal has `n` rows. Non-POSIX.

‘`cols n`’  
‘`columns n`’  
<span id="index-cols"></span> <span id="index-columns"></span>

Tell the kernel that the terminal has `n` columns. Non-POSIX.

‘`drain`’  
<span id="index-drain"></span> <span
id="index-nonblocking-stty-setting"></span>

Apply settings after first waiting for pending output to be transmitted.
This is enabled by default for GNU `stty`. It is useful to disable this
option in cases where the system may be in a state where serial
transmission is not possible. For example, if the system has received
the ‘`DC3`’ character with `ixon` (software flow control) enabled, then
`stty` would block without `-drain` being specified. May be negated.
Non-POSIX.

‘`size`’  
<span id="index-size"></span> <span id="index-LINES"></span> <span
id="index-COLUMNS-1"></span>

Print the number of rows and columns that the kernel thinks the terminal
has. (Systems that don’t support rows and columns in the kernel
typically use the environment variables `LINES` and `COLUMNS` instead;
however, GNU `stty` does not know anything about them.) Non-POSIX.

‘`line n`’  
<span id="index-line"></span>

Use line discipline `n`. Non-POSIX.

‘`speed`’  
<span id="index-speed"></span>

Print the terminal speed.

‘`n`’  
<span id="index-baud-rate_002c-setting"></span>

Set the input and output speeds to `n`. `n` can be one of: 0 50 75 110
134 134.5 150 200 300 600 1200 1800 2400 4800 9600 19200 38400 `exta`
`extb`. `exta` is the same as 19200; `extb` is the same as 38400. Many
systems, including GNU/Linux, support higher speeds. The `stty` command
includes support for speeds of 57600, 115200, 230400, 460800, 500000,
576000, 921600, 1000000, 1152000, 1500000, 2000000, 2500000, 3000000,
3500000, or 4000000 where the system supports these. 0 hangs up the line
if `-clocal` is set.

<span id="printenv_003a-Print-all-or-some-environment-variables"></span>

### 19.3 `printenv`: Print all or some environment variables

<span id="index-printenv"></span> <span
id="index-printing-all-or-some-environment-variables"></span> <span
id="index-environment-variables_002c-printing"></span>

`printenv` prints environment variable values. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
printenv [option] [variable]…
```

</div>

If no `variable`s are specified, `printenv` prints the value of every
environment variable. Otherwise, it prints the value of each `variable`
that is set, and nothing for those that are not set.

The program accepts the following option. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-0`’  
‘`--null`’  
<span id="index-_002d0-1"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dnull-1"></span> <span
id="index-output-NUL_002dbyte_002dterminated-lines-7"></span>

Output a zero byte (ASCII NUL) at the end of each line, rather than a
newline. This option enables other programs to parse the output even
when that output would contain data with embedded newlines.

<span id="index-exit-status-of-printenv"></span>

Exit status:

<div class="display">

``` display
0 if all variables specified were found
1 if at least one specified variable was not found
2 if a write error occurred
```

</div>

<span
id="tty_003a-Print-file-name-of-terminal-on-standard-input"></span>

### 19.4 `tty`: Print file name of terminal on standard input

<span id="index-tty"></span> <span
id="index-print-terminal-file-name"></span> <span
id="index-terminal-file-name_002c-printing"></span>

`tty` prints the file name of the terminal connected to its standard
input. It prints ‘`not a tty`’ if standard input is not a terminal.
Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
tty [option]…
```

</div>

The program accepts the following option. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-s`’  
‘`--silent`’  
‘`--quiet`’  
<span id="index-_002ds-25"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dsilent-7"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dquiet-10"></span>

Print nothing; only return an exit status.

<span id="index-exit-status-of-tty"></span>

Exit status:

<div class="display">

``` display
0 if standard input is a terminal
1 if standard input is a non-terminal file
2 if given incorrect arguments
3 if a write error occurs
```

</div>

<span id="User-information-1"></span>

## 20 User information

<span id="index-user-information_002c-commands-for"></span> <span
id="index-commands-for-printing-user-information"></span>

This section describes commands that print user-related information:
logins, groups, and so forth.

|                                                                      |     |                                                 |
|:---------------------------------------------------------------------|-----|:------------------------------------------------|
| • <a href="#id-invocation" accesskey="1">id invocation</a>           |     | Print user identity.                            |
| • <a href="#logname-invocation" accesskey="2">logname invocation</a> |     | Print current login name.                       |
| • <a href="#whoami-invocation" accesskey="3">whoami invocation</a>   |     | Print effective user ID.                        |
| • <a href="#groups-invocation" accesskey="4">groups invocation</a>   |     | Print group names a user is in.                 |
| • <a href="#users-invocation" accesskey="5">users invocation</a>     |     | Print login names of users currently logged in. |
| • <a href="#who-invocation" accesskey="6">who invocation</a>         |     | Print who is currently logged in.               |

<span id="id_003a-Print-user-identity"></span>

### 20.1 `id`: Print user identity

<span id="index-id"></span> <span
id="index-real-user-and-group-IDs_002c-printing"></span> <span
id="index-effective-user-and-group-IDs_002c-printing"></span> <span
id="index-printing-real-and-effective-user-and-group-IDs"></span>

`id` prints information about the given user, or the process running it
if no user is specified. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
id [option]… [user]…
```

</div>

`user` can be either a user ID or a name, with name look-up taking
precedence unless the ID is specified with a leading ‘`+`’. See
[Disambiguating names and IDs](#Disambiguating-names-and-IDs).

<span id="index-POSIXLY_005fCORRECT-8"></span>

By default, it prints the real user ID, real group ID, effective user ID
if different from the real user ID, effective group ID if different from
the real group ID, and supplemental group IDs. In addition, if SELinux
is enabled and the `POSIXLY_CORRECT` environment variable is not set,
then print ‘`context=c`’, where `c` is the security context.

Each of these numeric values is preceded by an identifying string and
followed by the corresponding user or group name in parentheses.

The options cause `id` to print only part of the above information. Also
see [Common options](#Common-options).

‘`-g`’  
‘`--group`’  
<span id="index-_002dg-7"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dgroup-2"></span>

Print only the group ID.

‘`-G`’  
‘`--groups`’  
<span id="index-_002dG-2"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dgroups"></span>

Print only the group ID and the supplementary groups.

‘`-n`’  
‘`--name`’  
<span id="index-_002dn-17"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dname"></span>

Print the user or group name instead of the ID number. Requires `-u`,
`-g`, or `-G`.

‘`-r`’  
‘`--real`’  
<span id="index-_002dr-13"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dreal"></span>

Print the real, instead of effective, user or group ID. Requires `-u`,
`-g`, or `-G`.

‘`-u`’  
‘`--user`’  
<span id="index-_002du-11"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002duser"></span>

Print only the user ID.

‘`-Z`’  
‘`--context`’  
<span id="index-_002dZ-7"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dcontext-7"></span> <span
id="index-SELinux-2"></span> <span id="index-security-context-8"></span>

Print only the security context of the process, which is generally the
user’s security context inherited from the parent process. If neither
SELinux or SMACK is enabled then print a warning and set the exit status
to 1.

‘`-z`’  
‘`--zero`’  
<span id="index-_002dz-17"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dzero-7"></span>

Delimit output items with ASCII NUL characters. This option is not
permitted when using the default format. When multiple users are
specified, and the `--groups` option is also in effect, groups are
delimited with a single NUL character, while users are delimited with
two NUL characters.

Example:

<div class="example">

``` example
$ id -Gn --zero
users <NUL> devs <NUL>
```

</div>

Primary and supplementary groups for a process are normally inherited
from its parent and are usually unchanged since login. This means that
if you change the group database after logging in, `id` will not reflect
your changes within your existing login session. Running `id` with a
user argument causes the user and group database to be consulted afresh,
and so will give a different result.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

<span id="logname_003a-Print-current-login-name"></span>

### 20.2 `logname`: Print current login name

<span id="index-logname"></span> <span
id="index-printing-user_0027s-login-name"></span> <span
id="index-login-name_002c-printing"></span> <span
id="index-user-name_002c-printing"></span> <span id="index-utmp"></span>

`logname` prints the calling user’s name, as found in a
system-maintained file (often `/var/run/utmp` or `/etc/utmp`), and exits
with a status of 0. If there is no entry for the calling process,
`logname` prints an error message and exits with a status of 1.

The only options are `--help` and `--version`. See [Common
options](#Common-options).

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<div class="header">

title="Table of contents">Contents</a>\]\[<a href="#Concept-index" rel="index" title="Index">Index</a>\]

</div>

<span id="whoami_003a-Print-effective-user-name"></span>

### 20.3 `whoami`: Print effective user name

<span id="index-whoami"></span> <span
id="index-effective-user-name_002c-printing"></span> <span
id="index-printing-the-effective-user-ID"></span>

`whoami` prints the user name associated with the current effective user
ID. It is equivalent to the command ‘`id -un`’.

The only options are `--help` and `--version`. See [Common
options](#Common-options).

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<span id="groups-invocation"></span>

<div class="header">

invocation</a>, Previous:
<a href="#whoami-invocation" accesskey="p" rel="prev">whoami
invocation</a>, Up:
<a href="#User-information" accesskey="u" rel="up">User information</a>
  \[<a href="#SEC_Contents" rel="contents"
title="Table of contents">Contents</a>\]\[<a href="#Concept-index" rel="index" title="Index">Index</a>\]

</div>

<span id="groups_003a-Print-group-names-a-user-is-in"></span>

### 20.4 `groups`: Print group names a user is in

<span id="index-groups"></span> <span
id="index-printing-groups-a-user-is-in"></span> <span
id="index-supplementary-groups_002c-printing"></span>

`groups` prints the names of the primary and any supplementary groups
for each given `username`, or the current process if no names are given.
If more than one name is given, the name of each user is printed before
the list of that user’s groups and the user name is separated from the
group list by a colon. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
groups [username]…
```

</div>

The group lists are equivalent to the output of the command ‘`id -Gn`’.

The only options are `--help` and `--version`. See [Common
options](#Common-options).

Primary and supplementary groups for a process are normally inherited
from its parent and are usually unchanged since login. This means that
if you change the group database after logging in, `groups` will not
reflect your changes within your existing login session. Running
`groups` with a list of users causes the user and group database to be
consulted afresh, and so will give a different result.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<span
id="users_003a-Print-login-names-of-users-currently-logged-in"></span>

### 20.5 `users`: Print login names of users currently logged in

<span id="index-users"></span> <span
id="index-printing-current-usernames"></span> <span
id="index-usernames_002c-printing-current"></span> <span
id="index-login-sessions_002c-printing-users-with"></span>

`users` prints on a single line a blank-separated list of user names of
users currently logged in to the current host. Each user name
corresponds to a login session, so if a user has more than one login
session, that user’s name will appear the same number of times in the
output. Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
users [file]
```

</div>

<span id="index-utmp-1"></span> <span id="index-wtmp"></span>

With no `file` argument, `users` extracts its information from a
system-maintained file (often `/var/run/utmp` or `/etc/utmp`). If a file
argument is given, `users` uses that file instead. A common choice is
`/var/log/wtmp`.

The only options are `--help` and `--version`. See [Common
options](#Common-options).

The `users` command is installed only on platforms with the POSIX
`<utmpx.h>` include file or equivalent, so portable scripts should not
rely on its existence on non-POSIX platforms.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

<span id="who-invocation"></span>

<div class="header">

</div>

<span id="who_003a-Print-who-is-currently-logged-in"></span>

### 20.6 `who`: Print who is currently logged in

<span id="index-who"></span> <span
id="index-printing-current-user-information"></span> <span
id="index-information_002c-about-current-users"></span>

`who` prints information about users who are currently logged on.
Synopsis:

<div class="example">

``` example
who [option] [file] [am i]
```

</div>

<span id="index-terminal-lines_002c-currently-used"></span> <span
id="index-login-time"></span> <span id="index-remote-hostname"></span>

If given no non-option arguments, `who` prints the following information
for each user currently logged on: login name, terminal line, login
time, and remote hostname or X display.

<span id="index-utmp-2"></span> <span id="index-wtmp-1"></span>

If given one non-option argument, `who` uses that instead of a default
system-maintained file (often `/var/run/utmp` or `/etc/utmp`) as the
name of the file containing the record of users logged on.
`/var/log/wtmp` is commonly given as an argument to `who` to look at who
has previously logged on.

<span id="index-am-i"></span> <span id="index-who-am-i"></span>

If given two non-option arguments, `who` prints only the entry for the
user running it (determined from its standard input), preceded by the
hostname. Traditionally, the two arguments given are ‘`am i`’, as in
‘`who am i`’.

<span id="index-TZ-4"></span>

Timestamps are listed according to the time zone rules specified by the
`TZ` environment variable, or by the system default rules if `TZ` is not
set. See [Specifying the Time Zone with
`TZ`](https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#TZ-Variable)
in The GNU C Library Reference Manual.

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options).

‘`-a`’  
‘`--all`’  
<span id="index-_002da-15"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dall-5"></span>

Same as ‘`-b -d --login -p -r -t -T -u`’.

‘`-b`’  
‘`--boot`’  
<span id="index-_002db-20"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dboot"></span>

Print the date and time of last system boot.

‘`-d`’  
‘`--dead`’  
<span id="index-_002dd-18"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002ddead"></span>

Print information corresponding to dead processes.

‘`-H`’  
‘`--heading`’  
<span id="index-_002dH-7"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dheading"></span>

Print a line of column headings.

‘`-l`’  
‘`--login`’  
<span id="index-_002dl-10"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dlogin"></span>

List only the entries that correspond to processes via which the system
is waiting for a user to login. The user name is always ‘`LOGIN`’.

‘`--lookup`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dlookup"></span>

Attempt to canonicalize hostnames found in utmp through a DNS lookup.
This is not the default because it can cause significant delays on
systems with automatic dial-up internet access.

‘`-m`’  
<span id="index-_002dm-12"></span>

Same as ‘`who am i`’.

‘`-p`’  
‘`--process`’  
<span id="index-_002dp-11"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dprocess"></span>

List active processes spawned by init.

‘`-q`’  
‘`--count`’  
<span id="index-_002dq-7"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dcount-1"></span>

Print only the login names and the number of users logged on. Overrides
all other options.

‘`-r`’  
‘`--runlevel`’  
<span id="index-_002dr-14"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002drunlevel"></span>

Print the current (and maybe previous) run-level of the init process.

‘`-s`’  
<span id="index-_002ds-26"></span>

Ignored; for compatibility with other versions of `who`.

‘`-t`’  
‘`--time`’  
<span id="index-_002dt-20"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dtime-8"></span>

Print last system clock change.

‘`-u`’  
<span id="index-_002du-12"></span> <span id="index-idle-time"></span>

After the login time, print the number of hours and minutes that the
user has been idle. ‘`.`’ means the user was active in the last minute.
‘`old`’ means the user has been idle for more than 24 hours.

‘`-w`’  
‘`-T`’  
‘`--mesg`’  
‘`--message`’  
‘`--writable`’  
<span id="index-_002dw-12"></span> <span id="index-_002dT-10"></span>
<span id="index-_002d_002dmesg"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dmessage"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dwritable"></span> <span
id="index-message-status"></span> <span
id="index-write_002c-allowed"></span>

After each login name print a character indicating the user’s message
status:

<div class="display">

``` display
‘+’ allowing write messages
‘-’ disallowing write messages
‘?’ cannot find terminal device
```

</div>

The `who` command is installed only on platforms with the POSIX
`<utmpx.h>` include file or equivalent, so portable scripts should not
rely on its existence on non-POSIX platforms.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

information.

| • <a href="#uname-invocation" accesskey="4">uname invocation</a>       |     | Print system information.          |
| • <a href="#hostname-invocation" accesskey="5">hostname invocation</a> |     | Print or set system name.          |
| • <a href="#hostid-invocation" accesskey="6">hostid invocation</a>     |     | Print numeric host identifier.     |
| • <a href="#uptime-invocation" accesskey="7">uptime invocation</a>     |     | Print system uptime and load.      |

<span id="date_003a-Print-or-set-system-date-and-time"></span>

### 21.1 `date`: Print or set system date and time

<span id="index-date"></span> <span
id="index-time_002c-printing-or-setting"></span> <span
id="index-printing-the-current-time"></span>

Synopses:

<div class="example">

``` example
date [option]… [+format]
date [-u|--utc|--universal] [ MMDDhhmm[[CC]YY][.ss] ]
```

</div>

The `date` command displays the date and time. With the `--set` (`-s`)
option, or with ‘`MMDDhhmm[[CC]YY][.ss]`’, it sets the date and time.

<span id="index-LC_005fTIME-6"></span>

Invoking `date` with no `format` argument is equivalent to invoking it
with a default format that depends on the `LC_TIME` locale category. In
the default C locale, this format is ‘`'+%a %b %e %H:%M:%S %Z %Y'`’, so
the output looks like ‘`Thu Jul  9 17:00:00 EDT 2020`’.

<span id="index-TZ-5"></span>

Normally, `date` uses the time zone rules indicated by the `TZ`
environment variable, or the system default rules if `TZ` is not set.
See [Specifying the Time Zone with
`TZ`](https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_mono/libc.html#TZ-Variable)
in The GNU C Library Reference Manual.

<span id="index-strftime-and-date"></span> <span
id="index-time-formats-1"></span> <span
id="index-formatting-times-1"></span>

If given an argument that starts with a ‘`+`’, `date` prints the current
date and time (or the date and time specified by the `--date` option,
see below) in the format defined by that argument, which is similar to
that of the `strftime` function. Except for conversion specifiers, which
start with ‘`%`’, characters in the format string are printed unchanged.
The conversion specifiers are described below.

An exit status of zero indicates success, and a nonzero value indicates
failure.

|                                                                       |     |                              |
|:----------------------------------------------------------------------|-----|:-----------------------------|
| • <a href="#Time-conversion-specifiers" accesskey="1">Time conversion 
 specifiers</a>                                                         |     | %\[HIklMNpPrRsSTXzZ\]        |
| • <a href="#Date-conversion-specifiers" accesskey="2">Date conversion 
 specifiers</a>                                                         |     | %\[aAbBcCdDeFgGhjmuUVwWxyY\] |
| • <a href="#Literal-conversion-specifiers" accesskey="3">Literal      
 conversion specifiers</a>                                              |     | %\[%nt\]                     |
| • <a href="#Padding-and-other-flags" accesskey="4">Padding and other  
 flags</a>                                                              |     | Pad with zeros, spaces, etc. |
| • <a href="#Setting-the-time" accesskey="5">Setting the time</a>      |     | Changing the system clock.   |
| • <a href="#Options-for-date" accesskey="6">Options for date</a>      |     | Instead of the current time. |
| • <a href="#Date-input-formats" accesskey="7">Date input formats</a>  |     | Specifying date strings.     |
| • <a href="#Examples-of-date" accesskey="8">Examples of date</a>      |     | Examples.                    |

<span id="Time-conversion-specifiers-1"></span>

#### 21.1.1 Time conversion specifiers

<span id="index-time-conversion-specifiers"></span> <span
id="index-conversion-specifiers_002c-time"></span>

`date` conversion specifiers related to times.

‘`%H`’  
hour (‘`00`’…‘`23`’)

‘`%I`’  
hour (‘`01`’…‘`12`’)

‘`%k`’  
hour, space padded (‘` 0`’…‘`23`’); equivalent to ‘`%_H`’. This is a GNU
extension.

‘`%l`’  
hour, space padded (‘` 1`’…‘`12`’); equivalent to ‘`%_I`’. This is a GNU
extension.

‘`%M`’  
minute (‘`00`’…‘`59`’)

‘`%N`’  
nanoseconds (‘`000000000`’…‘`999999999`’). This is a GNU extension.

‘`%p`’  
locale’s equivalent of either ‘`AM`’ or ‘`PM`’; blank in many locales.
Noon is treated as ‘`PM`’ and midnight as ‘`AM`’.

‘`%P`’  
like ‘`%p`’, except lower case. This is a GNU extension.

‘`%r`’  
locale’s 12-hour clock time (e.g., ‘`11:11:04 PM`’)

‘`%R`’  
24-hour hour and minute. Same as ‘`%H:%M`’.

‘`%s`’  
<span id="index-Epoch_002c-seconds-since"></span> <span
id="index-seconds-since-the-Epoch"></span> <span
id="index-beginning-of-time"></span> <span
id="index-leap-seconds-1"></span>

seconds since the Epoch, i.e., since 1970-01-01 00:00 UTC. Leap seconds
are not counted unless leap second support is available. See
[%s-examples](#g_t_0025s_002dexamples), for examples. This is a GNU
extension.

‘`%S`’  
<span id="index-leap-seconds-2"></span>

second (‘`00`’…‘`60`’). This may be ‘`60`’ if leap seconds are
supported.

‘`%T`’  
24-hour hour, minute, and second. Same as ‘`%H:%M:%S`’.

‘`%X`’  
locale’s time representation (e.g., ‘`23:13:48`’)

‘`%z`’  
Four-digit numeric time zone, e.g., ‘`-0600`’ or ‘`+0530`’, or ‘`-0000`’
if no time zone is determinable. This value reflects the numeric time
zone appropriate for the current time, using the time zone rules
specified by the `TZ` environment variable. A time zone is not
determinable if its numeric offset is zero and its abbreviation begins
with ‘`-`’. The time (and optionally, the time zone rules) can be
overridden by the `--date` option.

‘`%:z`’  
Numeric time zone with ‘`:`’, e.g., ‘`-06:00`’ or ‘`+05:30`’), or
‘`-00:00`’ if no time zone is determinable. This is a GNU extension.

‘`%::z`’  
Numeric time zone to the nearest second with ‘`:`’ (e.g., ‘`-06:00:00`’
or ‘`+05:30:00`’), or ‘`-00:00:00`’ if no time zone is determinable.
This is a GNU extension.

‘`%:::z`’  
Numeric time zone with ‘`:`’ using the minimum necessary precision
(e.g., ‘`-06`’, ‘`+05:30`’, or ‘`-04:56:02`’), or ‘`-00`’ if no time
zone is determinable. This is a GNU extension.

‘`%Z`’  
alphabetic time zone abbreviation (e.g., ‘`EDT`’), or nothing if no time
zone is determinable. See ‘`%z`’ for how it is determined.

<span id="Date-conversion-specifiers-1"></span>

#### 21.1.2 Date conversion specifiers

<span id="index-date-conversion-specifiers"></span> <span
id="index-conversion-specifiers_002c-date"></span>

`date` conversion specifiers related to dates.

‘`%a`’  
locale’s abbreviated weekday name (e.g., ‘`Sun`’)

‘`%A`’  
locale’s full weekday name, variable length (e.g., ‘`Sunday`’)

‘`%b`’  
locale’s abbreviated month name (e.g., ‘`Jan`’)

‘`%B`’  
locale’s full month name, variable length (e.g., ‘`January`’)

‘`%c`’  
locale’s date and time (e.g., ‘`Thu Mar  3 23:05:25 2020`’)

‘`%C`’  
century. This is like ‘`%Y`’, except the last two digits are omitted.
For example, it is ‘`20`’ if ‘`%Y`’ is ‘`2019`’, and is ‘`-0`’ if ‘`%Y`’
is ‘`-001`’. It is normally at least two characters, but it may be more.

‘`%d`’  
day of month (e.g., ‘`01`’)

‘`%D`’  
date; same as ‘`%m/%d/%y`’

‘`%e`’  
day of month, space padded; same as ‘`%_d`’

‘`%F`’  
full date in ISO 8601 format; like ‘`%+4Y-%m-%d`’ except that any flags
or field width override the ‘`+`’ and (after subtracting 6) the ‘`4`’.
This is a good choice for a date format, as it is standard and is easy
to sort in the usual case where years are in the range 0000…9999.

‘`%g`’  
year corresponding to the ISO week number, but without the century
(range ‘`00`’ through ‘`99`’). This has the same format and value as
‘`%y`’, except that if the ISO week number (see ‘`%V`’) belongs to the
previous or next year, that year is used instead.

‘`%G`’  
year corresponding to the ISO week number. This has the same format and
value as ‘`%Y`’, except that if the ISO week number (see ‘`%V`’) belongs
to the previous or next year, that year is used instead. It is normally
useful only if ‘`%V`’ is also used; for example, the format ‘`%G-%m-%d`’
is probably a mistake, since it combines the ISO week number year with
the conventional month and day.

‘`%h`’  
same as ‘`%b`’

‘`%j`’  
day of year (‘`001`’…‘`366`’)

‘`%m`’  
month (‘`01`’…‘`12`’)

‘`%q`’  
quarter of year (‘`1`’…‘`4`’)

‘`%u`’  
day of week (‘`1`’…‘`7`’) with ‘`1`’ corresponding to Monday

‘`%U`’  
week number of year, with Sunday as the first day of the week
(‘`00`’…‘`53`’). Days in a new year preceding the first Sunday are in
week zero.

‘`%V`’  
ISO week number, that is, the week number of year, with Monday as the
first day of the week (‘`01`’…‘`53`’). If the week containing January 1
has four or more days in the new year, then it is considered week 1;
otherwise, it is week 53 of the previous year, and the next week is
week 1. (See the ISO 8601 standard.)

‘`%w`’  
day of week (‘`0`’…‘`6`’) with 0 corresponding to Sunday

‘`%W`’  
week number of year, with Monday as first day of week (‘`00`’…‘`53`’).
Days in a new year preceding the first Monday are in week zero.

‘`%x`’  
locale’s date representation (e.g., ‘`12/31/99`’)

‘`%y`’  
last two digits of year (‘`00`’…‘`99`’)

‘`%Y`’  
year. This is normally at least four characters, but it may be more.
Year ‘`0000`’ precedes year ‘`0001`’, and year ‘`-001`’ precedes year
‘`0000`’.

<span id="index-literal-conversion-specifiers"></span> <span

‘`%%`’

‘`%n`’

‘`%t`’

<span id="Padding-and-other-flags-1"></span>

#### 21.1.4 Padding and other flags

<span id="index-numeric-field-padding"></span> <span
id="index-padding-of-numeric-fields"></span> <span
id="index-fields_002c-padding-numeric"></span>

Unless otherwise specified, `date` normally pads numeric fields with
zeros, so that, for example, numeric months are always output as two
digits. Most numeric fields are padded on the left. However, nanoseconds
are padded on the right since they are commonly used after decimal
points in formats like ‘`%s.%-N`’. Also, seconds since the Epoch are not
padded since there is no natural width for them.

The following optional flags can appear after the ‘`%`’:

‘`-`’  
(hyphen) Do not pad the field; useful if the output is intended for
human consumption. This is a GNU extension. As a special case, ‘`%-N`’
outputs only enough trailing digits to not lose information, assuming
that the timestamp’s resolution is the same as the current hardware
clock. For example, if the hardware clock resolution is 1 microsecond,
‘`%s.%-N`’ outputs something like ‘`1640890100.395710`’.

‘`_`’  
(underscore) Pad with spaces; useful if you need a fixed number of
characters in the output, but zeros are too distracting. This is a GNU
extension.

‘`0`’  
(zero) Pad with zeros even if the conversion specifier would normally
pad with spaces.

‘`+`’  
Pad with zeros, like ‘`0`’. In addition, precede any year number with
‘`+`’ if it exceeds 9999 or if its field width exceeds 4; similarly,
precede any century number with ‘`+`’ if it exceeds 99 or if its field
width exceeds 2. This supports ISO 8601 formats for dates far in the
future; for example, the command `date --date=12019-02-25 +%+13F`
outputs the string ‘`+012019-02-25`’.

‘`^`’  
Use upper case characters if possible. This is a GNU extension.

‘`#`’  
Use opposite case characters if possible. A field that is normally upper
case becomes lower case, and vice versa. This is a GNU extension.

Here are some examples of padding:

<div class="example">

``` example
date +%d/%m -d "Feb 1"
⇒ 01/02
date +%-d/%-m -d "Feb 1"
⇒ 1/2
date +%_d/%_m -d "Feb 1"
⇒  1/ 2
```

</div>

You can optionally specify the field width (after any flag, if present)
as a decimal number. If the natural size of the output of the field has
less than the specified number of characters, the result is normally
written right adjusted and padded to the given size. For example,
‘`%9B`’ prints the right adjusted month name in a field of width 9.
Nanoseconds are left adjusted, and are truncated or padded to the field
width.

An optional modifier can follow the optional flag and width
specification. The modifiers are:

‘`E`’  
Use the locale’s alternate representation for date and time. This
modifier applies to the ‘`%c`’, ‘`%C`’, ‘`%x`’, ‘`%X`’, ‘`%y`’ and
‘`%Y`’ conversion specifiers. In a Japanese locale, for example, ‘`%Ex`’
might yield a date format based on the Japanese Emperors’ reigns.

‘`O`’  
Use the locale’s alternate numeric symbols for numbers. This modifier
applies only to numeric conversion specifiers.

If the format supports the modifier but no alternate representation is
available, it is ignored.

POSIX specifies the behavior of flags and field widths only for ‘`%C`’,
‘`%F`’, ‘`%G`’, and ‘`%Y`’ (all without modifiers), and requires a flag
to be present if and only if a field width is also present. Other
combinations of flags, field widths and modifiers are GNU extensions.

<span id="Setting-the-time-1"></span>

#### 21.1.5 Setting the time

<span id="index-setting-the-time"></span> <span
id="index-time-setting"></span> <span
id="index-appropriate-privileges-1"></span>

You must have appropriate privileges to set the system clock. For
changes to persist across a reboot, the hardware clock may need to be
updated from the system clock, which might not happen automatically on
your system.

To set the clock, you can use the `--set` (`-s`) option (see [Options
for date](#Options-for-date)). To set the clock without using GNU
extensions, you can give `date` an argument of the form
‘`MMDDhhmm[[CC]YY][.ss]`’ where each two-letter component stands for two
digits with the following meanings:

`MM`  
month

`DD`  
day within month

`hh`  
hour

`mm`  
minute

`CC`  
first two digits of year (optional)

`YY`  
last two digits of year (optional)

`ss`  
second (optional)

Note, the `--date` and `--set` options may not be used with an argument
in the above format. The `--universal` option may be used with such an
argument to indicate that the specified date and time are relative to
Universal Time rather than to the local time zone.

<span id="Options-for-date-1"></span>

#### 21.1.6 Options for `date`

<span id="index-date-options"></span> <span
id="index-options-for-date"></span>

The program accepts the following options. Also see [Common
options](#Common-options). Except for `-u`, these options are all GNU
extensions to POSIX.

‘`-d datestr`’  
‘`--date=datestr`’  
<span id="index-_002dd-19"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002ddate-1"></span> <span
id="index-parsing-date-strings"></span> <span
id="index-date-strings_002c-parsing"></span> <span
id="index-arbitrary-date-strings_002c-parsing"></span> <span
id="index-yesterday"></span> <span id="index-tomorrow"></span> <span
id="index-next-day-1"></span> <span id="index-last-day-1"></span>

Display the date and time specified in `datestr` instead of the current
date and time. `datestr` can be in almost any common format. It can
contain month names, time zones, ‘`am`’ and ‘`pm`’, ‘`yesterday`’, etc.
For example, `--date="2020-07-21 14:19:13.489392193 +0530"` specifies
the instant of time that is 489,392,193 nanoseconds after July 21, 2020
at 2:19:13 PM in a time zone that is 5 hours and 30 minutes east of
UTC.  
Note: input currently must be in locale independent format. E.g., the
LC_TIME=C below is needed to print back the correct date in many
locales:

<div class="example">

``` example
date -d "$(LC_TIME=C date)"
```

</div>

See [Date input formats](#Date-input-formats).

‘`--debug`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002ddebug-1"></span> <span
id="index-debugging-date-strings"></span> <span
id="index-date-strings_002c-debugging"></span> <span
id="index-arbitrary-date-strings_002c-debugging"></span>

Annotate the parsed date, display the effective time zone, and warn
about potential misuse.

‘`-f datefile`’  
‘`--file=datefile`’  
<span id="index-_002df-22"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dfile-1"></span>

Parse each line in `datefile` as with `-d` and display the resulting
date and time. If `datefile` is ‘`-`’, use standard input. This is
useful when you have many dates to process, because the system overhead
of starting up the `date` executable many times can be considerable.

‘`-I[timespec]`’  
‘`--iso-8601[=timespec]`’  
<span id="index-_002dI_005btimespec_005d"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002diso_002d8601_005b_003dtimespec_005d"></span>

Display the date using an ISO 8601 format, ‘`%Y-%m-%d`’.

The argument `timespec` specifies the number of additional terms of the
time to include. It can be one of the following:

‘`auto`’  
Print just the date. This is the default if `timespec` is omitted.

‘`hours`’  
Append the hour of the day to the date.

‘`minutes`’  
Append the hours and minutes.

‘`seconds`’  
Append the hours, minutes and seconds.

‘`ns`’  
Append the hours, minutes, seconds and nanoseconds.

If showing any time terms, then include the time zone using the format
‘`%:z`’. This format is always suitable as input for the `--date` (`-d`)
and `--file` (`-f`) options, regardless of the current locale.

‘`-r file`’  
‘`--reference=file`’  
<span id="index-_002dr-15"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dreference-5"></span>

Display the date and time of the last modification of `file`, instead of
the current date and time.

‘`--resolution`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002dresolution"></span>

Display the timestamp resolution instead of the time. Current clock
timestamps that are output by `date` are integer multiples of the
timestamp resolution. With this option, the format defaults to
‘`%s.%N`’. For example, if the clock resolution is 1 millsecond, the
output is:

<div class="example">

``` example
0.001000000
```

</div>

‘`-R`’  
‘`--rfc-email`’  
<span id="index-_002dR-8"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002drfc_002demail"></span>

Display the date and time using the format ‘`%a, %d %b %Y %H:%M:%S %z`’,
evaluated in the C locale so abbreviations are always in English. For
example:

<div class="example">

``` example
Mon, 09 Jul 2020 17:00:00 -0400
```

</div>

<span id="index-_002d_002drfc_002d822"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002drfc_002d2822"></span>

This format conforms to Internet RFCs
[5322](https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc5322),
[2822](https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc2822) and
[822](https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc822), the current and previous
standards for Internet email. For compatibility with older versions of
`date`, `--rfc-2822` and `--rfc-822` are aliases for `--rfc-email`.

‘`--rfc-3339=timespec`’  
<span id="index-_002d_002drfc_002d3339_003dtimespec"></span>

Display the date using a format specified by [Internet RFC
3339](https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc3339). This is like `--iso-8601`,
except that a space rather than a ‘`T`’ separates dates from times, and
a period rather than a comma separates seconds from subseconds. This
format is always suitable as input for the `--date` (`-d`) and `--file`
(`-f`) options, regardless of the current locale.

The argument `timespec` specifies how much of the time to include. It
can be one of the following:

‘`date`’  
Print just the full-date, e.g., ‘`2020-07-21`’. This is equivalent to
the format ‘`%Y-%m-%d`’.

‘`seconds`’  
Print the full-date and full-time separated by a space, e.g.,
‘`2020-07-21 04:30:37+05:30`’. The output ends with a numeric
time-offset; here the ‘`+05:30`’ means that local time is five hours and
thirty minutes east of UTC. This is equivalent to the format
‘`%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S%:z`’.

‘`ns`’  
Like ‘`seconds`’, but also print nanoseconds, e.g.,
‘`2020-07-21 04:30:37.998458565+05:30`’. This is equivalent to the
format ‘`%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%N%:z`’.

‘`-s datestr`’  
‘`--set=datestr`’  
<span id="index-_002ds-27"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dset"></span>

Set the date and time to `datestr`. See `-d` above. See also [Setting
the time](#Setting-the-time).

‘`-u`’  
‘`--utc`’  
‘`--universal`’  
<span id="index-_002du-13"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002dutc"></span> <span
id="index-_002d_002duniversal"></span> <span
id="index-Coordinated-Universal-Time"></span> <span
id="index-UTC"></span> <span id="index-Greenwich-Mean-Time"></span>
<span id="index-GMT"></span> <span id="index-leap-seconds-3"></span>
<span id="index-TZ-6"></span> <span id="index-Universal-Time"></span>

Use Universal Time by operating as if the `TZ` environment variable were
set to the string ‘`UTC0`’. UTC stands for Coordinated Universal Time,
established in 1960. Universal Time is often called “Greenwich Mean
Time” (GMT) for historical reasons. Typically, systems ignore leap
seconds and thus implement an approximation to UTC rather than true UTC.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
